number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Solid game that is, in my opinion, hurt by a reliance on luck.I may come back and do an expanded review later, but for now I'll keep this short. The game on its face is fun, but the combat relies HEAVILY on random dice rolls. A string of bad rolls WILL mean that you fail a mission, no matter how skilled you are or how well you've built your characters. Add to that the enemies seeming to get very powerful cards just a little ways into the game (rank 7 missions, and even earlier) and it can get immensely frustrating incredibly quickly. It may be that enemies have smaller decks than the player characters do, which means key cards (armor, powerful attacks, etc) come up more than they do for the player, or it may just be my poor luck, but at the end of the day, when no amount of strategy can win in the face of a string of bad luck, I can't recommend this game. In my opinion, a certain degree of luck in games is fine, but when the ability to even make an attack comes down to luck of the draw, I think that hurts the game. It's not a bad game by any means when the other components are taken into consideration (art is good, the tone of the game is humorous, and the mechanics for character progression and deck building are fun) but it is very frustrating when battles are won or lost based almost purely on RNGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												TL;DR I would not recommend CardHunter. The game mechanics are interesting and fun but it is pay-to-not having to grind and you are playing an RPG without story or immersion or atmosphere.It is such a shame that a really great idea for mechanics is wasted because of greediness (asking money for content and loot) and laziness (no story, animations, atmosphere).PROs:- Game mechanics are unique and interesting. It is basically a puzzle game (which gear to equip for which battle) meet tactical combat a la XCOM.- The whole "meta" aspect - you play someone who is playing a game - is funny (for about 15 minutes).CONs:- The devs ask you every 5 seconds for real money. Big portions of the game are only available when paying for it. Image that in The Witcher you are being asked to pay 4 Euros to enter this dungeoun. The game really is all about loot (cards). Every single action a character can perform - even to walk - comes from cards which come from equipment. Loot is everything, levels are nothing. Now, you can grind your way to victory over countless hours or simply pay cash to get loot. At the same time, the  price per month is about the same as for a triple A MMORPG, WTH?- Multiplayer is very asymmetrical, players do not get even chances because single player loot is used.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Card Hunter did make a decent first impression with the interesting table-top theme and selected mechanics.  Other reviewers have covered those well enough.I gave it a fair shake with over a dozen hours of play this week so I'm here to tell you that playing this game beyond the first impression is awful.  The table-top theme becomes very burdensome, limiting the maps to roughly 1/3-1/2 of a 16:9 monitor.  The fancy dice or whatever that you see in the screenshots are useless borders.The "DM" is a series of running jokes about pizza, pimples, living in Mom's basement, etc.  They provide ZERO atmosphere to the game but constantly interrupt the flow of your party's grind as you have to acknowledge each inane comment to continue playing.In addition to being tiny, the maps are exceedingly boring combinations of terrain squares.  The art is so bad that you have to examine each tile to get an understanding of the intended impact on movement or line of sight and good luck remember them all.  Once you've decided how your party will be built, you'll play every map exactly the same way.Multiplayer is immediately accessible since your multiplayer team is max level.  You still have to grind for equipment, however, although I see that you can purchase ready-made and equipped teams for multiplayer games.  One team is provided, armed and ready, for free.  Multiplayer, however, is exactly the same as playing generic campaign boards only with (sometimes) superior intelligence.  I enjoyed the handful of games I played, then watched a couple of more games, and never felt the need to try it again.Anyways, I wanted to love it but recommend giving this one a pass.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Name: Card HunterDeveloper: Blue ManchuDate: 2013Genre: Card Tactics, CCGPopulation: AlivePerspective: 2.5D - IsometricTimeflow: Match-Based, Turn-Based, Fast-PacedSkills: BrainSetting: FantasyStyle: TabletopTags: RPG ElementsModel: F2PContent: Collectible, Microtransactions, SubscriptionPlatforms: PC, Mac, BrowserReview: Tabletop styled fantasy mix of tactics, RPG and CCG. You have a table, game master, plain paper battle map, different papers with stats, story and all other info; dices, decks, characters in form of plain cardboard tokens, and sounds that fit tabletop atmosphere perfectly. I mean the style is 11/10. It received "PC Gamer: Most Original Game of the Year 2013" award - I guess that was the main reason, because... gameplay is pretty boring as for me.	Every battle you control 3 characters: Warrior, Mage and Cleric. Each character has his own deck, and item slots. Each equipped item adds its cards to that character deck. Yes they don't give any stats, there are actually no stats at all (but hp) and no auto-attacks. Character levels increase amount of item slots and hp.	So, for example your Warrior deck has 40 cards. His Rare Sword gives him 6 cards, including 1 Rare Smash, 2 Uncommon Punches and 3 Common Strikes. Uncommon Boots give him 1 Uncommon Run, 1 Common Walk and 1 Common Weak Armor. Common Shield gives him 2 Common Blocks and 1 Common Armor. And so on.	Each round all characters draw 3 cards from their decks, with only exception that at least 1 card will always be Move card. So yes, there will be situations when your Warrior has drawn all Armor cards and won't be able to attack till next round at best. Each turn player chooses 1 card of 1 character and plays it. When all players passed the turn, all characters choose 2 cards and discard the rest, and next round begins.	Just like in any CCG, there are a lot of nuances like line of sight, direction the unit is facing, terrain types, armor and penetration mechanics based on dice rolls, buffs/debuffs, trait cards that have to be played at yourself at the beginning of round, terrain enchantments, knockbacks, damage types (crushing, piercing, lightning, arcane, etc.) and... well I don't know them all because I only played few hours :O	Campaign seems to be pretty huge - the map is, at least, and I only discovered several missions - a tiny part of it. Each mission has few battles on different terrain with different monsters and a (simple) story. And the loot, of course - you get new equipment and/or "treasure" items which are only good to sell. Go to the shop between missions, sell them and buy something you actually need. You can change equipment between battles and before the next try, if you lost. You only have 3 tries and then you have to restart mission. 	Surprisingly, goals don't always end up being "kill everything", some are interesting. There are also Treasure Hunts, which are only unlocked with premium currency which is Pizza Slices :p	Multiplayer should be fun as well, but I didn't try it since you have to level up your characters and get some cards in campaign first to get there, and I did not ;p There are dailies also, as far as I know.	Microtransactions are used for levels, cosmetics and items. I can't say for sure, since I didn't play much but the game doesn't look like P2W. Steam reviews also say it's not. With premium you get 1 extra loot item each battle, some hidden levels, you can buy more things in shop and therefore probably collect Rare cards faster. But just like in GOOD CCGs, luck with drops and patience decides much more.	So why my verdict here is No, and why is it No without doubts? 2 things. 	First, I don't like how Cards are drawn. I don't know if it's the style or just lack of talent, but this is just TOO simple. Check screenshots. I mean I could draw such art, too, and these are not empty words. I understand this isn't MTG with its several dozens professional artists, most of which dedicated whole life drawing fantasy. But come on, this is CCG after all. There is no way I am collecting cards that look like 10y.o drawing. Characters, monsters, terrain, illustrations - everything else looks fine.	And second - as for me, gameplay is boring - maybe original, but boring. There is no excitement when you do smart tactical decisions and win, which I have in Hearthstone or MTG.	P.S. Don't forget - there are ABSOLUTELY no animations in game, except poorly made spell effects. Since it is Tabletop-styled. You don't have much animations when you play board games, do you? Facial expressions don't count ^^Class: III - BreadVerdict: NoReviewed: 8.24.2015Approach: Steam - PCTime: Several HoursDeeds: 1 Achievement

												Card Hunters features a lot of interesting ideas, but these ideas are bogged down by a wide variety of basic problems, the biggest of which is the fact that it is a pay-to-win game.Some of the smaller problems this game features include the fact that you can't sell gear you don't need for way longer than makes sense, the game is a grindfest that decides you can't grind at dungeons that don't meet the arbitrary level range based off your own level, and Melvin. Seriously, Melvin sucks. These issues didn't seem like such a problem to me when I first played this game on a flash games site, but as a steam game I feel like it's not up to snuff.Unless you really enjoy card-based combat featuring module art and other aesthetics that try really hard to look reminiscent of the first two editions of D&D, I wouldn't recommend Card Hunters

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												There are good free-to-play games (e.g.- Dota2, Path of Exile) and bad ones (e.g.- anything by Zynga). Unfortunately, this falls squarely into the latter category.It's a clever concept, no doubt. And despite some trashy pitfalls (your "GM" is an utter unlikable fellow, and I'm sick of his voice already), the fundamentals like combat mechanics, pacing, and interface are decent. But it's the F2P "features" that weasel their way into the game that really suck the fun out of it.First, the big one: you can't repeat quests more than once per day. This is what really turns me off. Once you've run what's on the map, you're done. Go play something else. This is a direct result of their F2P model: it artificially limits your characters, and paying "Pizza" (their in-game currency) allows you to bypass this somewhat.Second, despite what others have said, there *are* pay-to-win features here. It's not all cosmetic.Third, they shove it in your face. There's a "membership club" (read: pay us for more items), which awards more loot at the end of dungeons. Regardless of whether you've signed up or not, they roll an item reward and lock it if you're not a member.I get it. Casual gaming is a tough market, and getting free-to-play right is hard. Too much and your game looks like a trashy ebay ad; too little and you don't get a paycheck. That said, they didn't even come close to the right balance here.I'll pass, thanks.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												Meh.   Interesting game play.  The graphics are about what you'd expect for a java based game, but if you're playing this game you probably are much more interested in the atmosphere and game play.Each dungeon is basically a set of room battles, and cards are dealt to both sides that they can use during the fight to move, heal, hack... etc.  The biggest issue for me was that after each room battle was completed, your health and card deck was completely reset, so worrying about future battles at all doesn't play into the current battle. Progression of your characters is somewhat stiffled if you don't purchase an extra loot "slot" that gives you an extra toy after you win a fight, increasing your chances of getting better gear.  The game has other areas littered with pay for play "opportunities", which in my opinion is never justified, although for a game of this caliber, is plain silly on a computer platform.  This game is belongs on I-pads or other such limited computing power devices, and is probably a little below average in those markets.  All in all, if you have an game pad, X-Box or are 12 years old, this game may hold some limited draw for you.  It's definetely not a D&D tribute, or even that in depth.   But for a free download, it could hold your attention for a couple days if you're an RPG or adventure fan.I do applaud the effort though.  We neeed more games like this in the genre, but a more depth and challenge would be nice for me.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												'Sunset. Or maybe dawn? Who knows..', Cuddlepie thought.It felt like days ago when he and his friends last saw the sky. They had been crushing and slashing their way through zombies and skeletons for too long, way too long. Mr Jingles had already fallen... Wouldn't be long before fatigue got the best of him also.  'Damn our luck..', he mumbled. Their cart crashed probably at the worst place ever. He just knew that cottage was bad news. He could feel it, and his fears proved correct when the dead appeared and never stopped coming. They had hoped it would be just a few, easy to get rid of. But that was just wishful thinking.Boppsy made a tough decision, but it was the right one. Perhaps someone else would have ignored the sinister laughs and the cries for help from the cottage and just run away. But not them. It was obvious that whatever evil lurked inside the cottage had to be dealt with, once and for all.  'By me beard, young lady, FOCUS!'. His thoughts were interrupted by Boppsy's fierce voice.  'I am trying, you silly dwarf! I already put that giant skeleton in the other cell, do you think teleporting others is as easy as swinging a hammer?' The wizard replied  'Perhaps you 'd like to do it then!', Boppsy laughed back, while breaking another skeleton in pieces. 'Cuddlepie, are you ready?'  'Always, brother', I replied.We had finally reached the last chamber of the cottage and I was staring at the evil necromancer for some time now, only few meters ahead of me, yet so far away. The lava between us was impassable. I was exhausted but I was also ready to strike with my most powerful combo. Boppsy was right behind me, succesfully holding off the endless waves of the necromancer's minions at the narrow corridor between the two jail cells. The young, imprisoned wizard was in one of the cells, trying her best to help Boppsy and teleport me next to the necromancer for the fatal blow.The necromancer was mocking us, throwing spells without caring if we die now or later...  'Finally!!!', I heard a faint yell. And time stoppedI tried my best to hold my senses. I had prepared my all out attack and now I also had the perfect block ready. My vision blurred and a split second later I was next to the evil necromancer. He didn't seem worried nor afraid I was next to him and he lifted his weapon to crush me down...No, I wasn't expecting that. In my surprise I desperately threw my shield up while dashing on the right. It blocked his swing and he lost his balance, and he wasn't ready at all for my reckless swing that hacked him from shoulder to bottom.The chaos had stopped.RNG, as much as I f#!@&% hate you, Card Hunter has also taught me to love you.

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Alright, as you can see I've put 90 hours or more into this game in just two weeks. Admittedly, some of that was me leaving the game on. But I digress.As others have said, this game starts off as fun, but challenging. Around the level 6-7 area is where the game actually begins to get more fun and challenging at the same time. it is a very fun and satisfying experience when you overcome a very stacked battle against your adventurers, but soon the tedium sets in and you start to see the unfair difficulty in spades. Soon you realize just how stacked odds are against you when you actually play and count the number of random dice rolls and the like in a fight and how the game *Perhaps* manipulates the battles and cards as you play.Example : You and your party are up against armor shredding enemies who have 2 space attack cards that go through armor and 1 space attack cards that discard all your armor cards. These enemies only pull 13-16 cards at the beginning of the match and they are for the most part 90% good cards. Enemies have "Failure" cards such as discarding all blocks, or discarding all attacks, which can mean you'll have an easier time for that round and perhaps the next. The problem is, that they usually have cards better than yours, and the game knocks you down levels so you can't come back with great gear.So you decide to run a party mix of warrior, priest, and mage. Positioning is VERY important in this game. You sometimes need to play "Hold back" or "Aggressive" in order to win. Look at the board, notice line of sight, basic strategem. Understood, right? Thing is, if you make "one" mistake, a party member is dead because it is usually 5+ VS 3...or in some cases 13-14 against 3. Albeit some mobs of enemies come as one...so its 3 goblins as "1" enemy who shares cards and usually have little hp.So you begin the fight, and you get your hand of cards. You stacked your priest for heals, you stacked your mage for long-range damage, and you stack your warrior for tanking/medium strikes. Your mage sees a mob in range, she/he casts a spell. The enemy mob has at least 2 block cards and 1 missile reflect on turn one. These cards have rolls of 3-4 to deflect, so thats a 50%-60% chance they will fail....but you have to roll all three times. After 90 hours of play, I know that these rolls are indeed not as random as they officially appear. And sometimes you want one to be blocked, but instead a lower chanced one will activate.I have recorded how many times my mages spells have been "Reflected" instead of "Blocked" by cards with far higher  chances. My spell will go under the missile block and be reflected...followed by a block. Now you may be saying "Just go melee it, then?" right? So I change the strategy, use my warrior....If I use all my movement to get my healer and warrior into position, my warrior backstabbing (Like a rogue) to bypass blocks and my healer being able to heal....the 2+ enemies who are stacked against you will indeed backstab your warrior in return usually wounding him/her down to 5-9 hp...or worse, killing them outright.The thing is, each round the game gives you a certain amount of cards from your "Deck" but I've noticed the deck gives you only 1-2 options for the approach to minimize damage/loss each round. Try it yourself and I am sure you will find the same findings. I've recorded how often I've been "Punished" by the gm for trying to finish off a mob when the gm (Ai) has decided "You have done enough damage this turn. Pass now, or you will regret it." and lost a match. The enemies somehow have "just" the right cards to screw your party if you do anything but what the game wants you to do.The game doesn't really have as much luck as you think it does. In my 70+ hours of play, I've noticed my party fails rolls around 33% more than enemies do. If you manage to bypass enemy blocks, and damage AKA....look at the game board, look at all the possible movement, and "Hope" that the enemy doesnt have 2 pocket moves/super smash/instant kill cards...and you'll win. That takes time, imagine if you had to plan every move in real D&D for 5-10 minutes to make sure your warrior won't get blitz krieged when you pass your turn or better yet, your warrior is in perfect aoe chop range....you stacked 12 chops in your deck...and none come up for 3 turns. I get 2-3 rounds in a row where I have no attack cards and an enemy has ~10-12 Hp left and it drags on to tedium. I stack my decks for builds, but my "attack" cards all sink to the bottom or when they do come up, I'm so far out of range that they're useless. There was once a fight where I had to occupy squares against 5 enemies, and even though I've beaten it consecutively since then, I once sighed in frustration because a "Healer" priest on the other side....was down to 10 HP. My warrior had a 14 damage attack I "saved" for 2 turns to finish her. My mage only had a sneak along walls movement, I snuck up behind her, occupied a sqare, force blasted her into my warrior's lap and....She pulled out a pocket Mighty Bludgeon, my warrior failed "All" 3 of his armor rolls with 1's and the match was over in a blink. Stuff like this happens "Often". Way too often. The only way to win this game? Put about 100+ hours farming purples from matches you've already beaten until you can "Overgear" for the new fight...and beat this crooked system. I can't even get my money back, but I did have at least some fun before the game got unfair.So please, login to the game, read the chat, you'll hear the same thing. Don't listen to people who have put in less than 20-30 hours into this. They haven't hit "The Wall" I climbed the wall, I've won against ogres, demons, cthulhu, and everything else....but its not worth it. its not worth the twenty dollars I put into this crooked game.

Posted: July 26, 2015
												This game requires its own set of login credentials on top of those required by Steam, defeating the point of Steam as both DRM and user authentication.The accounts cannot be altered or deleted, and because made a mistake when creating mine, I can't play, and the developers aren't interested in changing this behavior. The only redress is a long process in which I have to justify my reasons for asking for a new account (I haven't even played yet) in writing. This practice clearly wasn't considered. As a computer user I have dozens of authentication sets that I have to track without adding every single game I play. Every publisher that adds an additional login layer thinks that they are special - that I should make this exception for them. They give reasons that they think are sufficient to justify the policy. They're wrong. I wouldn't track extra logins for the other 190+ games that I own; why would I track yours?

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
As thematic and boring as THAC0Card Hunter's premise is that you are playing a pen-and-paper role playing game that is run by Gary, a novice game master, who is bullied by his neckbeard brother, and has a crush on the hot pizza delivery girl. These brief interludes before every campaign mission are easily the best part of the game. They do a great job of capturing the humor and nostalgia of every nerd's high school pen-and-paper role playing sessions. Sadly, these story sections don't really mesh with the gameplay. Gary introduces the missions, but there's never any dialog during the combat. It feels like someone wrote the story and then the combat system was farmed out to a different team. The gameplay just isn't as fun as the story.The first big problem is all those Cards you're Hunting. Each item that you equip adds its entire set of 3 or 6 ability cards to your character's deck. If you understand basic UI design (unlike the Card Hunter devs), you'd probably expect the game to have a character screen that clearly shows which cards each piece of equipment is adding to your deck. Maybe with a column of equipment slots, with each item's cards shown to the side. But they didn't do that. So maybe your second guess would be that all the cards in your deck are at least organized sensibly, so that if your mage's deck contains two Firestorm cards from his staff, and a third Firestorm from a magic ring, the devs would at least program the game to give you the OPTION of clearly showing those three Firestorm cards all together, presumably beside any other fire spells that are in your deck, right? WRONG AGAIN! This cool cards-from-equipment idea was handled in the WORST way possible - each item's cards are just squished against each other in the deck, without any sorting or clear visual boundary between the sets of cards. And to make things even worse, some missions will force you to change much of your equipment (for example, you'll need lots of attacks that hit multiple enemies for a mission that swarms you with goblins) but there's no way to easily switch between "decks" (equipment loadouts), so you're stuck wrestling with the terrible interface much more than you should have to.Oh, and when you're browsing a shop (there are several, presumably just to make shopping more frustrating, since there's no danger or cost involved in moving between stores) whenever you mouseover an item so that you can actually see what its cards are there's a cute little unrolling scroll animation before you get to see what its cards are. And no, it can't be disabled. You have to endure it every... single... TIME when you're just trying to slog through your mess of equipment. (Did I mention that I've put several hours into the game but still haven't earned the right to sell crappy equipment? I know you get to sell junk eventually, but it takes way too long to show up.) Cards have some basic numbers to show how much damage they do and their maximum range (although these don't increase to reflect passive buffs), but anything more complicated than that requires you to zoom in on the card to read a mess of confusing keywords that should have been replaced with icons. (The keywords are such a mess that some "piercing" type weapons do "penetrating" damage that ignores armor. Really?! You had to use two different terms that have the same meaning everywhere but in your game? You couldn't call them "thrusting" or "stabbing" weapons?)Next problem - movement! I like games where the position of your units is important, but movement is very cumbersome here. You can't move unless you have a card that specifically lets you, and you can't "save" some of its movement for later in the turn. Combined with the fact that you only get to play one card before the enemy gets a turn, you will often run into infuriating situations where enemies move just out of range, making your hand full of attack cards useless. Each adventurer does always get a basic movement card in addition to whatever cards he randomly draws from his deck, so you're not completely reliant on getting lucky and drawing a movement card, but it just isn't enough.It's crucial to know how much health each character has left, but the number is often obscured (There are lots of alternate skins for your heroes that you can buy with real dollars, but their appearance doesn't change to show how bashed up they are). You can see your adventurers' health numbers at the bottom of the screen, but it's not shown as a health bar or anything else eye-catching like that. Just numbers.Here's a bonus tip for slogging through this review of all the game's problems: Gary will give you pizza (premium currency) so you can get a free taste of stuff that normally costs real money (such as hero skins) but the game lets you spend the pizza on actual useful stuff like club membership for bonus loot.

												Literally one of the worst games I've ever played. The gameplay and graphics are so-so, but what truly and utterly kills this pathetic excuse of a title is the RNG. You get a deck of however many cards, and from that you draw MOVE, ATTACK, and DEFENSE cards. Well, you'd freakin think that a warrior would always get an attack card, a cleric a heal, and a mage a spell, right? WRONG. Darn near EVERY fight, I've had to re-play due to this game's absolute GARBAGE RNG. My warrior draws NOTHING but movement, or my cleric never draws a heal, or my freakin mage draws up the three physical attack cards in her deck of 33. That happens EVERY fight. Not some, not most, EVERY fight. And then, these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ creators also have the gall to make enemies have one-shot cards that can outright KILL a PC but you struggle just to damage them due to the completely unbalanced armor and shield cards. You end up hitting a dude for 8? Yeah, he's gonna have 4 shields, each of which let him draw into more shields, or attacks. This title needs a serious balance overhaul. I will NEVER play it again. PS: If you're gonna make a D&D clone, maybe you should actually bleeping PLAY D&D once in a while to see what it's like. Your game makes me recall that trash movie with the wayans brother.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I reccomend this game as another timewaster and something of a decent quality. I do not however reccomend it as a game with any connection to what it satirizes. The gameplay is nice, the art is pretty decent, the humour is kinda bearable, but do not expect anything more than a grind and some story. They could have done much more, but they chose not to. There is no choice involved at all, no character customization beyond choosing 1 of the peices they sell and equipping gear with no visual component. The DM characters constantly remind you with bad jokes that your not playing anything resembling the games initial appearance. Its all fighting, getting gear and leveling up.If you want a game where you play levels, something like angry birds with a bit more stuff going on, then go ahead, its well made for that.If you had hoped for anything more, such as rolling a 20 sided die or any die, making choices with saving roles, etc, this is not that game. Its not even a card game, so dont expect that either.So im not saying its bad, im saying its not anything special and i dont reccomend mediocrity. Ill keep playing till im fed up, just to make sure i didnt jump the gun, but i doubt i did.

number of helpful: 4 of 19 people (21%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												This game is nothing but a huge disappointment:1. There's zero tactical depth and variety in this game because all kinds of damages are just direct damage (DD). If you're looking for interesting creature spells, you'll just be disappointed. Most attack cards in this game are either "Melee attack dealing 2/3/4/5/6/etc damages with a range of 2/3/4/5/6/etc tiles" or "Magic attack dealing 2/3/4/5/6/etc damages with a range of 2/3/4/5/6/etc tiles". Honestly, there's no creativity at all in card design.2. Ugly card artwork unless you think cards like this (http://wiki.cardhuntria.com/wiki/Cards/Stab) and this (http://wiki.cardhuntria.com/wiki/Cards/Strong_Stab) are eye candies.3. 100% Pay-to-Win: If you don't pay real money to buy chests that offer powerful items (in the forms of "rare", "epic" and "legendary" items), you won't have any chances at all to win in PvP. Yes, you might still beat low level PvPers equipped with cheap items. However, you'll definitely be killed by high level players who have spent hundreds of dollars on buying powerful gear. People who say this game isn't P2W are just blatantly lying. 4. Stupid storylline: Every quest is just "kill this evil character (insert name) to obtain this valuable item (insert name)". 5. No in-game deck builder. No in-game item and card database. Good luck wasting your time on Google.6. Mentally ret@rded AI: If your character has just 1 HP left and an AI enemy with attack cards in hand is next to him, don't worry! Because the AI enemy will just end the turn instead of using the attack cards to kill your character. The AI in this game is just dumb as hell. The developer only uses numerical advantage as the means to make AI enemies difficulty to beat in this game.7. Extremely slow development progress: Currently, there're only 3 races (human, elf, and dwarf) and 3 classes (warrior, priest, and wizard) available for team building. The player community has been asking for the 4th class (e.g., rogue) for over 1 year already, but the developer has done *NOTHING* at all in widening the range of class or race. Instead, the developer has only kept churning out adventure modules that offer stupid storylines and more powerful items to milk players' wallets. After all, as I stated above, the only way for you to stay competitive in PvP is to maintain an arsenal of powerful items. 8. The game server can be down without any explanation or prior notice from the developer. They're probably using a toaster to host the game.If you're looking for a digital card game with tactical depth and variety, go play Magic The Gathering Online. Don't waste your time and money on this sub-par title. I wish I could request a refund for the money spent on the campaign modules. According to the stats provided by Steam Charts, the number of peak players has tumbled by over 80% (a loss of around 5000 players) since the game was released on Steam a month ago. This hard fact is another strong evidence that Card Hunter is just a huge P2W disappointment.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I wanna recommend this game... but no. I fail to see what makes it worthy with the other games on steam. The baordgame style is enjoyable, the tutorial is thorough (even if it does a bit much of the hand holding). It fails in it's disguise of of free to play. Sure you can play for free but it quickly points out the things you won't get unless you pay. Even still, I don't have a problem with this system. You  get to play and see if you like it and just not buy if you don't find it enjoyable. What I have a problem with is the insane price jump for simple stuff. For $19.99 you get the actual game plus 100 pizza (in-game premium currency). That's crap when considering the game isn't worth $20- No voice-overs just odd sound effects for dialog pop-ups, no live action, pretty basic boardgame style play with nothing all that new brought to the table, and certainly nothing compelling for a $20 game and this title has the nerve to push for a monthly fee (that is optional but still thats some bs). I'm a frugal steam gamer. Thanks to steam sales, I've been able to enjoy amazing titles with little more than $20 (I tend to burn too much of that on beer and use the change for videogames :-() in my pocket at any given time. But this game will never compete with those deals (most recently Depth >$10 for a full game and crap my pants fun!). The price for pizza is between $4.99 to like $98.00 (150 and 3,800 slices respectfully)! That's insane! This can be used for premium gear as the game quickly points out 3.5 hours in. I have mobile games that are more cost effective than this with better graphics and sound.  Short and simple is this, if this game advertised itself as a $20 FULL game on steam it wouldn't get a 2nd look but I'd at least have more respect for it. There are waaaaay too many titles (especially the random badasses that go on 80-90% sales for no damn reason other than that the sun came up that day)  it can't compete with with at the same relative cost. This game hides it's price tag until play it and when it shows itself it is a bloated mess of cost. I would never recommend this game to my friends because with this cost structure they'd laugh at me, tell me to play Path of Exile, and to take note of how a real free to play game is suppose to be setup. Woof!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												The mechanics are fairly weird. A player may play one card (move OR attack OR other) on one of his characters, then the enemy does the same. Repeat until both can't do any moves any more (because they don't have moves left and the enemy is not in range for any attacks). As soon as a stalemate is reached and both players "pass" a new turn will begin (and you get new cards). If just one player has to pass, then the other can still burn through all his cards until he is done (and with the way movement is handled this happens a lot (more often to the enemy, but that's boring too)).And since moves are cards, with the way it works right now, you are really trying NOT to move up to the enemy and let them come to you, so that you can first strike.If your three guys fight against one enemy, then by the time all three had a chance to do something, the other guy will have had three actions. Right in one of the first fights there is an enemy who covers the ground in acid. And you have no way of getting out of it. He uses an aoe spell that puts more than one of your guys into acid. And if you use a move action to get out of the acid he just uses his skill on you again (because if it is 3v1, then he moves three times as much as you do). The fight is still very winnable. It just feels idiotic.I didn't enjoy this at all. Natural flow or pacing didn't develop at any point.And, of course, what everyone else said: pay2win.And a time waster game. You won't take anything from this that could be useful.Unless wasting time is what you are going for.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I gave it a shot free-to-play, trying to see why it had such good ratings on Metacritic.  I played for about 6 hours across 2 days and so far it's like watching corn grow, when it's not trying to sell me something...which is EVERY single time I play.  Cards are linked together in items, often include negatives, are repetitive, and do no damage to speak of.   Having the cards linked to items seriously hampers the deck-building aspects of the game. The dungeon playboards are extremely repetitive and having to repeat them to level another character is very tedious.Having to join a "club" to get additional loot items is also ludicrous.  I also note that more often than not the better items wind up being in the "club" slot.If you're into watching grass grow, being irritated by odd DM's, and restrictive repetitive cards then you might like it, but I'd advise everyone to step away from this one.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												This game has weird mechanics that leave you saying 'Oh come the ♥♥♥♥ on' way to many times, especially the fact that you can't move your characters without a move card. As you are only likely to get 1 move card per draw for the character, you will often find yourself stuck in the same position as enemies just walk away from you and you are unable to follow having used up your move card and you don't get new cards until you end your turn. This becomes very annoying when enemies start cover the floor with damage over time spells.The lack of the ability to move your characters around without a card to move is really, really annoying. Pure and simple. The fact that the enemy's constantly move away from you makes it even more annoying. The fact that some enemies make standing still punishment for you even even more annoying.Of course all your attacks also come in the form of cards. You cannot reuse them. You can have a character use up his 1-2 attacks and not really be able to do anything against the enemies around him unless you end the turn to redraw cards. Half of the games I played featured my dwarf sitting there doing nothing while being attacked simply because I wanted to use my other characters.I cannot stant the mechanics. Maybe if you only controlled 1 character at a time it would be more workable, but having your party stand around and do nothing but get hit while you're moving your mage around to do something, then having them hit again as you launch off a couple spells without doing much of anything isn't an enjoyable system.I do not recommend this game.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												Tl;dr at the boottomWhat it is : Card hunter is a tactical tabletop simulator focused on combat with Rpg elements sprinkled on top of it. How does it play out : You control an adventuring band of 3 heros ready to face all the dangers the land of cardhuntria has to offer. Your character's equipped gear determine the skills ( cards ) that can be used in battle, those skills ranges from moving cards to blocking cards to healing to utility and attack cards with merged cards that allow two actions i.e( attack and move ) . Said gear can be equipped in slots that you gain when you level up your characters. That gear is sperated into 5 catagories ( common, uncommon , rare, Epic and legendary ) with the rarer varity gaining you powerful skills, said gear is also further seperated into gear that require power tokens - which you gain from leveling up - power tokens are also seperated into minor and major power tokens, they serve no purpose but as a prequiste to equiping gear.Is it P2W : No, it is not. Spending money on the game yields you cosmetics and extra content, represented in more campaign modes i.e. ( citadel in the sky, attack of the artifacts) and treasure hunts that yields you a single Epic class gear.Is it fun : Extremely.Does have any flaws : Yes. As with all fun games you want more. I would have liked if it had more classes ( rogues , scouts..etc. ), out of combat focus even if it was just yes or no choices and steam work shop support for player created campaigns.Verdict : Very fun game to play with amazing content to match 8/10      Tl;dr : Xcom meets D&D in a weird card game like manner , easy to play hard to master, free to play , turn based , amazing content , paying unlocks more amazing content , wish it had more things to do other than combat.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												Tactical combat, card game skill mechanics, a vast array of collectibles, all wrapped in a candy-coating of old school D&D nostalgia... As a long-time tabletop, pen-and-paper gamer, I was instantly drawn to Card Hunter. If you fondly remember The Keep on the Borderlands, if you can recognize art by Erol Otus with your eyes closed, or if you can state how many sides a certain polyhedral die has without counting them, you'll respect what this game is trying to do.I say "trying", because although I really enjoy it, it doesn't capture the D&D experience unless your GM was all about plot-lite combat scenarios. As such, it doesn't really match the description or the cute commercials it has. But it doesn't have to; it's still a fantastic turn-based, fast-paced strategy game. The core of the strategy is about matching your equipment to your play-style for your 3 party members, a mixture of humans, dwarves, and elves who are either warriors, clerics, or mages. (It would be nice to see a halfling rogue in the mix, with stealth moves and backstabbing and whatnot, but they're easy to overlook. Har, har!) Once you've geared up, you take your party through a number of cleverly-illustrated modules to gain experience and loot, which give you both more equipment slots and better cards to choose from during combat. The design works well, and gives you ample opportunity to try out new strategies to get past scenarios that are challenging for your current build.There is a bit of a grind-wall, which requires you to replay the same module several times to level up enough to get through the next tier. However, I'm willing to admit that might just be my stubborn adherence to my party's current build. Maybe I didn't have to get to level 8 to get through the level 7 modules. I could just suck. :) That's also why I steer clear of the multiplayer -- you get rewards that you share with your campaign characters, but in a game that doesn't *require* PvP, I give it a pass. From the little of it that I played, the other gamers seem polite and helpful, which is nice to see.If you fondly remember the early years of D&D and are looking for an engaging turn-based game, and if you love filling your characters' inventory with countless possible upgrades, definitely give Card Hunter a try. And while you're at it, bust out your original copy of the Monster Manual and give your Rust Monster a hug today!

Posted: October 14, 2015
												Ok, lets get this straight to avoid any confusion.  This game has nothing to do with roleplaying games, but what it does have a lot to do with is classic fantasy boardgames, like talisman, dungeon, or heroquest.  Unfortunately this is marred by the whole having to pay to unlock certain features and bonuses, and in the pvp section this really does show as to who pays and who's here just for fun. There are a few stereotypes which immediately feel out of place, especially as this isn't 1986 and games like this are far more mainstream these days, so the depiction of everyone who plays this as a nerd hurts more than helps.Ok, on to the game itself, past the cringe-worthy imagery.  What I will say here is that everything that follows is why I gave it a  positive thumb waving.They have for the most part, got themselves a really good package here, with board based tile movement and card based combat.  You fight all of the fantasy stereotypes of goblins, orcs and other such things.  The combat is resolved by using cards for each adventurer that you have until you find you can't use any more, due to running out, or just not having the right card at the right time, like in the video where the guy says 'I cast a lightning bolt!' etc.  At the end of every round the adventurers and remaining monsters get to draw new cards.  This can be a little difficult to catch when the game uses the terms 'rounds' and 'turns' applying htem to what they want.  Movement can only take place if you have movement cards, and I don't see any indicator to show when you're arriving at the end of the round.  So tactics like waiting for the monsters to move and expend their cards for movement/attack before you make your decisions aren't really possible.  If you do try to estimate that, then you could end up in a poor position, as if you have over two cards per adventurer left at the end of the turn, then you have to discard them until you have the sacred number of 2 for some reason.The amount of money you gain is determined by how much treasure detritis you find after each battle, which usually comes in quite low amounts, so most of the time you will depend on the other treasure items you find to equip your adventurers.I would recommend this game, but only if you want a very superficial experience and aren't looking for anything with more depth than your 12 year old brother might be looking for in a fantasy board game.   Maybe good for an hour on the weekend with your favourite intoxicant/food-snack while still wearing your p.js perhaps.

												This game was exactly what I was looking for. I love card based games in the real world, but don't always have others to play against. This one will sometimes really make you think, as sometimes the cards you get won't be ideal - just like any real stategist game. Work with what you have. Cards available to each character will vary depending on what is in the deck for that character, and that is based on what items are equipped to the character. Because of this, no scenerio will ever play out exactly the same, even if you've already played that level before. Levels also follow storylines, so if you like to feel like you're fighting for a specific cause, you'll have one. Stop those gnolls from eating the villagers!

												Long before Card Hunter arrived on Steam, I was obsessed with it. It's a perfect combination of an old school dungeon-spelunking aesthetic and a newfanged deck-building card engine. 												Great game! I love the board game style, the sound effects, and the humor! Simple and intuitive gameplay mechanics, a good balance of strategy and luck, quick turns, and a well-constructed rewards and leveling-up system (yes, even without paying for the membership) allow me to play this game co-op with my two kids and still enjoy playing it alone or with other grown-ups. Posted: September 5, 2015
												An amazing little turn-based tactical strategy game with an old school fantasy RPG flavor.  Position your adventurers on a grid map and do battle with monsters using the spells and fighting techniques represented by cards that your adventurers get from the equipment you choose to equip them with.  It has a decent competative MOBA multiplayer as well as a 2-3 player co-op campaign.  The purple prose of the modules provokes just the right amount of nostalgia to invoke OG Dungeons and Dragons.  The competative balance ebbs and flows with each expansion, but is generally pretty good.  The difficulty of the singleplayer/coop campaign varies WILDLY depending on the specific scenerio, any handycaps you may choose to apply, and how you spec your toons.Expansions/DLC are fun and flavorful if somewhat short and occationally punishingly hard.Overall a very nicely designed TSG with a good deal of depth and a strong competitive following.  Can be a little hard even for a vetern of the genre in places, the campaign does get stale after a while, and it can be frustrating to grind for a single high level item among the multitude of random drops, but these complaints pale in comparison to the game's many charms.

But I recommend you to buy 1 of any bundle, it will make your card collecting progress faster. (+supporting the dev!)- So many builds you want to try em all.- Helpful community.- Long Single Player Campaign.- very balanced, nothing OP, every builds has their counter. and it really depends on your luck + skill.- Leagues. if you're bored with normal mp games.- Co-op.Cons:- No matter how good your build, if RNG god hate you, you'll lose.

												Wow, what a cool little game and it's great that it's free (with in game payments if you want to do that).This is a game all about quick tactical combats while your group of fantasy adventurers are out making their legend.  The game revolves around the CCG element where you use certain cards to do different powers.  The cards you have are dictated mainly by the gear you find and equip which you earn from doing questsYou can choose from three races (Human, Elf, Dwarf) and three classes (Warrior, Mage, Priest).  It doesn't sound like much considering that so many games have so many optionsYou can play solo, co op with friends or other randoms or even play ranked vs others you don't know. I honestly thought I'd just get this and go yeah it's free and kill a few hours with it, but I quickly became addicted.  It's fast, fun and I love the way combats flow.Give it a try.

												An interesting combination of 2 types of game: tactical role-playing and card game will drown you into a fantastic adventure. Posted: July 18, 2015
												For those of us who were nerds and played the classic D&D, AD&D, and all the other iterations of this genre, there is so much that's familiar with it that brings back memories.  For those of us who were into Magic when it came out and are still involved w/ it or it's various forms, this game should be very comfortable w/ you too, since it is a card based combat system that is driven on the type of gear that you have.  This makes you want to collect everything since the mini-campaigns require you to customize your equipment loadout so that you have the cards to succeed in them. Lastly, for those of us who have played a bizillion  F2P games, this game should be one of your favs b/c of the minimal in your face, hard sale, micro transaction, premium status type models that you so commonly see. All in all, this game is a great combination of all three, that imo combines many of the great traits of the above mentioned game types w/o bogging you down.  It ties everything together w/ a lightly humourous, sarcastic campaign narration and a very engaging game play system that hooks you and threatens to destroy human relationships b/c you're hooked on trying to complete that next mini-campaign or do the next PvP or co-op. :p  The entire system is relatively simple to understand and is easy to get into quickly.  That is it's best and worst traits.  Limited with a 3 character party, with 3 playbable races, and 3 playable classes; there are calls about expanding party size, race and classes.  If this happens, like in any developing game that starts out great and fun, game play and balancing issues will inevitably occur.   As it stands though right now, it's a great and fun game to play either in PvP, Co-op, or campaign settings  that entices you  to actually pay for the premium account so that you can unlock expansion campaigns and extra loot.

Posted: December 12, 2015
												A very enjoyable single player game, and even more fun when you get to play with a couple of your buddies. This game brings the fun and joy of card games to your computer. When I play this, I get the feeling of DnD as well, especially with the special mission boards they give you. The game also has very good humor and jokes mixed in. Anyways, here are the basics. You can have fun playing as three different characters, a healer, a mage, and a warrior. From there, you can pick different races for the character, such as an elf, a human, or a dwarf. After you create the character, you get various equipment to put on your character to give them different cards. This is the general gameplay and setup and it's so satisfying trying to come up with strategies with the cards you have to win your matches. With this game being free and such, there is nothing lost at least giving this little gem of a game a try.

												Pretty decent as far as turn based strategy RPGs go. The combat system is interesting since every action is determined by your cards, which are determined by your gear. A weapon might give a character more damaging cards, cards with more range or cards with special effects, armor works the same way for defensive and movement skills. All in all, it's ok to play in short bursts. The free to play model errs on the more expensive side, which is unfortunate since the genre isn't one where paid content would offer much over the free stuff.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												OK, when i first saw the game in PCGamer or something, i thought - "This game is probably full of microtransactions, as every free-to-play game. It looks childish, the genre is not my type... this is gonna suck". Before you know it, the game is installed. So i start it expecting to quit after 5-10 minutes. So we go to battle, i get a dwarf or some sh*t, who by the way walks like a retar*ed penguin. Next we have a magician who thinks he's Dumbledore. And we have a priest, or shaman or whatever. Ok this is like D&D, maybe it'll be fun. After like five turns not knowing what i'm doing, i'm like "i don't see myself playing this, probably gonna uninstall after the battle". So now i get the game, but guess what: i'm surrounded and i'm like "HEY! get away from my priest you a hole!" So i break the encirclement like the Ivan at Stalingrad, using the dovahkiin-looking warrior, mad dumbledore skills and fus-ro-dah teleportation skills. I WON! Maybe this isn't so bad after all. Next i face a big-as* dragon. Full of confidence i'm like : "Give me you best shot young Alduin" So now Alduin is spiting some sh*t on me, cant move, slowly dying. He approaches and now i'm like "fus-ro-dah motherf**ker" as i teleport him, i finish him off with my Tyrion Lannister-looking kind of guy. Battle is over and i scream: "In your face Alduin, who's the dovahkiin now, huh?" So my brother asks me: "What are you playing? I didn't know you had Skyrim installed" - "No, it's some D&D kind of game, i just rap*d Alduin" He loked at me with a strange, somewhat terrifying look, and after few seconds said "OK". My mom called me and asked if i was feeling alright.So yeah, this game turned out quite different than i expected, don't look at my playing time, i will definitely play a lot more of this game. You might think as a free-to-play game it must have microtransactions. Whell, acutally no. You can buy different types of versions that get you something, but nothing that changes the gameplay or give any significant advantage. If you have five minutes or wan't a marathon game, play it. It's free, fun and fair, which is not that common this days. this game was made because the devs love the games and the genre, making a very good game, try it.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												Do not let my short play-time fool you: I have been playing Card Hunter since it was first released as a browser-based title, and have logged hundreds of hours into grinding several adventurers and digging for loot. There are few games I can stand behind so much as this one - all the best features of turn-based tactical games and collectible card games come together to make this epic design that has sucked away countless hours of my life. The campaign mode is bar-none excellent, and PVP is far more elegantly balanced than one might think. Epic and Legendary cards aren't necessarily more powerful than the rares and uncommons you can pick up as a free player, so a clever player will PWN ALL in PVP if your build works well and you're able to out-think your opponent in play.This is not some make-a-buck-fast TCG or some unbalanced Tactics cash-in. This is a game that belongs on every computer, and I stand behind what I say here. You will not be disappointed; it is endless hours of awesomeness.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												This game is amazing! It's a mix of RPG,TCG, and Xcom. If that makes you at all excited then try it out! If not, then try it out anyway! It's Free! I have had so much fun that I decided to pay $20 for the Basic Pack to support the devs. The only con so far is the connectivity issues, and those are already being worked on. I would recommend to play the game with friends. However that doesn't mean that the singleplayer isn't fun, I often will hop in to the singleplayer inbetween Co-Op sessions to level my characters and get more loot. The community is friendly and helpful, and the devs have been friendly (haven't interacted with them myself but a bit of browsing the steam forums for this game proves this). I have yet to be frustrated with this game, even when RNG wasn't with me on the card draws I wasn't raging, I was figuring out how to kit myself better for the situation. Just... Check this game out!!

Posted: July 16, 2015
												I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who grew up playing Dungeons and Dragon or who enjoys tactical board games. The art direction is perfectly suited for the medium and every card, icon, and character is easy to comprehend. The adventures are cleverly written to evoke the classic D&D style with a subtle sense of humor. From a gameplay standpoint, Card Hunter scratches that itch for meaningful descisions with the random card elements. By equipping different items before each battle, you can stack your deck with specific cards more suited to overcome the challenges. This will be essential to be able to continue as this game is quite challenging and most maps will require careful turn-by-turn planning and a bit of luck to be able to win. Don't hesitate to re-equip or shop for new items if the enemies are immune to a damage type or have a gimick attack.As a free game it scores major points for not including any obnoxious elements like a limitation on play. The cash shop currency is optional and you can complete the singleplayer adventures with the default rewards. Overall this is easily the best tactical board game available on Steam.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												This is the best free turn based strategy game I've ever played.It has solo, 2-3 player coop and versus. So you can enjoy it however you want.The best part about the game is the item system. Each character have a deck of cards like attacks, armor, move, block... This deck is made by the items your character has equiped. Each item gives between 3 and 6 cards. But, it's all or nothing. If an item have 5 great cards and an handicap, you have to deal with it. This makes for very unique character building that can be optimized in a lot of ways.There is also 3 classes and 3 races for characters that all have items that can exclusively be equiped to them.There is a freaking lot of items in this game and, yep, it's free to play, you can buy more items. But it's not really a problem to me. You will lack some items in the begining but if you play through a good part of the campaign, you'll have a lot of them. If you want to help the devs your options are : timed subscription for an extra item after each fight, buying individual chests with guaranteed high rarity items and new side-missions with guarantee item the first time you complete it. None of those are required to truly enjoy the game. There is also some character reskin you can buy that doesn't affect gameplay at all.(If you want to buy the missions, the bundle isn't you only option. If you go on the lock mission, you'll be able to unlock it for some paid currency which is a better deal if you don't care about the rest of the bundle.)The campaing itself it very fun. Each mission is a different challenge with unique opponents. I've yet to complete it. The missions get harder and harder, often requiring you to change your items to match specific opponents. I've started it again with a friend and it still is a blast to play.But, the story is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Don't expect anything from that part.An amazing strategy game that gives you a lor of options and always harder challenges. Solo, coop and versus, all are amazing!

Posted: July 27, 2015
												So far (62 hours played) this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played.Likes:- Well-built, runs smoothly and no crashes.- Looks good, original artwork that suits its slightly wacky style.- Entertaining gameplay in matches.  Most are challenging enough to be fun without being frustrating.  Some are very challenging, making you think carefully about team build and every card you play.- Interesting party building.  Three classes, three races and a huge number of loot cards gives enough variety to make your parties feel unique.- Good value for money.  I bought one expansion, which gives me a months club membership and few other bits, but I am quite certain you can play the campaign without struggling for free.  Multiplayer does have the capacity for being influenced by spending money, but at my level I've not seen any of that.- Fun PvP.  Played about 10 matches so far.  All players I have met have been friendly and only one or two matches have been one-sided.  The others have been nicely balanced and very entertaining.- Awesome humour.  If you every played much PnP Dungeons and Dragons, this game will make you smile and chuckle constantly.- Good community.  The world chat is mostly good-natured.  For a competitive game there is a surprising lack of leetness and rage.Dislikes:- Literally not found any yet.  I suspect that if I get to high-rating PvP, balance issues might start to appear, but none so far.

Posted: May 20, 2016
Product received for free
												An excellent buy for the price of nothing! The game has a sense of rewarding tactics (Hot Spot all the way!), and nice board-gamey feel. It takes off quite slow, which can be frustrating, but gets increasingly more challenging and interesting. The card based combat system offers a nice balance on luck, tactics and strategy. I do recommend, and easy addition to any game library, a few easy game hours if you're looking to kill some time.

Free to play, so I suggest you at least play the tutorial, it's well done and fun to play. Then you will see for yourself if you got what it takes to be an adventurer! ;)

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Card Hunter is an awsome game. You can play it solo, coop, and PvP ; all modes are fun !  It looks like an DnD adventure, where you have rounds, an you and the enemy take turns to play. You may play cards from you're hand, which changes every turn (since you draw), and those cards come from the build you give to each characters.This kind of building allows you to create a lot of different possible options, which makes running the game over and over again, like if you'd played for the first time ! :)You can play the game without paying anything, though the dlc gives more maps to play through, which is kind of fun.If I could suggest any buys, I would recommand the first "Basic Edition" game, and the other AI Bundle (5,99$). This way, you should make enough pizza to buy all the other maps from Citadel (require only when you reach max level) without paying (if I'm not mistaken). Though buying the second dlc gives another subscription month and some kool figurines. You're call ^^Whatsoever, this games has my vote ! Always fun to play, mostly coop, with friends or people online. Enjoy !

Posted: May 8, 2016
												I am not great at reviews.Card Hunter is basically a tactical-board game where you have three characters who each have their own deck composed of items that you equip to them and the character's race (of Human, Elf, Dwarf, I would be happy to see more, but I have played this game since before it was on Steam and it has only ever had the three).I am unaware of any pay to win aspects in the game. There are microtransactions, but they are cosmetic, or for expansion packs, which I am okay with. Most of the stuff you can buy seems reasonably priced to me, your mileage may vary.The game itself can be frustrating at times, as there is a lot of rng-madness going on. Some games you'll draw non-combat card after non-combat card despite having a deck on the character that consists of a great many combat cards. Other games you'll get a plethora of combat cards, but not enough ways to actually move to opponents, which leads to having to discard all of your lovely cards.Most matches run fairly well though, I have had many good runs where I felt everything went well, but when playing with rng, you are going to come up to points that are frustrating.The art style of the game is clear and enjoyable. The campaign story isn't terrible, though the meat of the game is the tactical combat, so the story isn't a major focus.I recommend the game, it is a good pick-up-and-play game, lightly casual, but with enough depth to sink into.

Posted: July 15, 2015
												This is a bit of a mixed bag, but not for the reasons you'd think.As a freemium title, you'd expect it to be rife with pay-to-have-fun features and short on content. It is neither of those things. What you get instead is a fun little throwback to old school AD&D, complete with a perfect mimicry of the art and writing styles of that era of game design. And my god, it even plays like old DnD - just a simplified, reasonable version, dressed up with some crunchy deck-building mechanics. It's accessible, it's charming, and above all it's fun. It's a gem of a game.So, why is Card Hunter a mixed bag? The answer to that is Gary and Melvin.Campaign mode in Card Hunter is basically a three-character story. Gary is your GM, Melvin is his older brother, and then there's a girl from a pizza place. The pizza girl is totally fine as a character. Gary and Melvin make me writhe in my chair. Imagine, if you will, a hobby shop. Imagine this hobby shop is in a crappy part of your city. Imagine its windows are so heavily plastered with comics and action figure ads from the 1970, all of which are faded and peeling and stuck on with tape. Imagine that you've gone inside this store, wrinkling your noise at the powerful funk of old books and spilled snackfood that fills the cramped, dirty space within. Imagine there's only one customer, fat and unwashed, paging idly through Bikini Mail Magazine. And now imagine that behind the cracked, ancient counter, lounging in a pool of his own adipose folds, is a forty-something man in a pit-stained old t-shirt and sweatpants, hyucking softly to himself as he optimizes his WoW build on his laptop.Now imagine you've collapsed that entire experience into a single person. That person is Melvin.Gary is not much better. Thanks to Gary and Melvin, Card Hunter is a wild roller coaster of highs and lows. You'll fight a sharkbear, and that'll be pretty cool. Then Gary will say something cringing and miserable and you'll want to claw your own eyes out. You'll perservere, though, and get to see some righteous module art about cannibal yetis living in a blizzard. And then Melvin will open his mouth and you'll dream about just punching him. Punching him until he stops moving. Punching him FOREVER.I've never seen a game ooze social awkwardness like this one, and it's a damn shame, because everything else about it is great. The devs clearly are familiar with old school DnD. They get what tabletop culture used to be like.And then they choose to make the faces of Card Hunter a distillation of all the worst parts of the people who play the hobby.Maybe they hate themselves?

Posted: August 2, 2015
												Card Hunter is a very unique experience; i would very loosely call it a mix of D&D, TCG to an extent but omitting the trading part of TCG and Chess. The graphics are not next generation and on the loading screen it says "A game only limited by your imagination" which is very true; if your expecting some next generation graphics this aint the game. Card Hunter's main premise is build around loot. You can dungeon for loot, battle other players online for loot, enter a league with special play/win conditions you wont find anywhere else for even better loot if you do well and as well you can buy loot, using the in-game currency known as 'Pizza' delivered by a pizza company donning the name of the development company, 'Blue Manchu'. I myself have bought a little bit of loot and the pay to win aspect you'd expect to be present gets kind of drowned out by the skill actually required to play the game and assemble an effective deck; in the time it will take you to learn the game, you will have earned probably the same amount of loot as you would just buying some off the start and not playing much of the content it has to offer and so in this sense, the game is not pay to win. When you get loot from dungeons or online, there is a loot club you can also sub to, using pizza, to get an extra roll off the chest; You can easily afford the 7 day membership to this club with the free pizza your given in-game throughout the beginning of the campgain and then finish the campgaign and get all the member loot you would miss if you didn't have it, but again, your use of whatever you get from these free rolls will only be dictated by your skill at the game and time spent, so its not really pay to win.The battles themselves are, by many who play this game, considered to be 'mentally taxing' and it is true, in battle your margine for error is very low. Basically, most maps will have a 'VS' or victory square, to which you can move your character to, and your character will sit on these points and control them; at the end of the round, if you control more points, you get a 'VP' or victory point, stating that you control the points, you get a single point. If he kills one of your chracters however, your opponent will get 2 'VP' and so although the 'VS' or victory squares are important, character management is far more important and these two factors working together in the game serve to create a very intense experience with low margine for error if you want to win. There are 6 VP's to gain in total and 3 characters on each team, so if you wipe his team, even if your losing on the Victory Squares, you can still come back and win.The races you can choose have a profound effect on the board; Elves are movement based and usually get 2-3 movement cards rather than just the standard 1 movement card every turn, but have the lowest HP of all the races. Dwarves have higher hit points, but are the slowest race. Humans are dynamic and have commands they can use to make their team members move, or draw cards and are considered to be the average race with average health and average movement. Getting in depth with classes is not necessary; there is the warrior, cleric and mage. Very simple. How you play these classes in context to what race you choose to play the class as will basically define your experience in the game and is a big choice to make right off the bat, considering you'll have spent no time playing the game before initially making this choice to choose race/class. Considering this game is free, it is a steal of a deal and i highly recommend you atleast try the game out; yes there is content that is behind a pay wall, however if you enjoy the game and think its well thought out and created, maybe 'Blue Manchu' deserves to make a little cash off it, huh? =)

												I have to say I really like this game.  Lots of nostalgic feelings from my old D&D days of pen and paper play. I play with my friends and it is a blast, especially when you get defeated by a scenario and have to rethink strategy and card deck to over come it (hopefullY) on the second, sometimes third, try.  I truly think that the negative reviews are from people that just arent very good at this type of game, or just arent very bright.  Luck is a part of it but not as much as some people say.  And hey, its free!

Posted: October 22, 2015
												Long before Card Hunter arrived on Steam, I was obsessed with it. It's a perfect combination of an old school dungeon-spelunking aesthetic and a newfanged deck-building card engine. You can have plenty of fun for free, and there's no need to spend any money unless you want to speed up your progression (useful but not necessary to complete the campaign) or unlock the expansion content. The developers are also very open to the community on social media, and I like to feel that I contributed in a small way by helping to get the original war monkeys nerfed!

Posted: October 23, 2015
												Strikes a surprisingly good balance of fun vs profit for a pay2win game.The single player campaign is well tuned and will leave you wanting more, which is where the independently purchasable modules come in. Since you're purchasing actual content, it doesn't leave you feeling sullied when you hand over the cash, even if the individual purchases ultimately add up to the cost of a AAA game.The power token system ensures that even very early game loot will have a place in your end-game party builds. Higher level gear requires more and more tokens, you'll never possess enough tokens that you can deck your character entirely in high level gear. It's a clever idea, and well implemented.I haven't touched the multiplayer, but this is where, I imagine, the pay2win issues are a little more at the forefront. There are no item rarity restrictions, and legenday / rare items are a very powerful and central part of many pvp builds.Protip: When starting out, you'll be given pizza to spend on costumes and chests. You don't have to do so. Spend that pizza on card hunter club membership instead, it will make playing the campaign much more enjoyable.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												Tl;dr at the boottomWhat it is : Card hunter is a tactical tabletop simulator focused on combat with Rpg elements sprinkled on top of it. How does it play out : You control an adventuring band of 3 heros ready to face all the dangers the land of cardhuntria has to offer. Your character's equipped gear determine the skills ( cards ) that can be used in battle, those skills ranges from moving cards to blocking cards to healing to utility and attack cards with merged cards that allow two actions i.e( attack and move ) . Said gear can be equipped in slots that you gain when you level up your characters. That gear is sperated into 5 catagories ( common, uncommon , rare, Epic and legendary ) with the rarer varity gaining you powerful skills, said gear is also further seperated into gear that require power tokens - which you gain from leveling up - power tokens are also seperated into minor and major power tokens, they serve no purpose but as a prequiste to equiping gear.Is it P2W : No, it is not. Spending money on the game yields you cosmetics and extra content, represented in more campaign modes i.e. ( citadel in the sky, attack of the artifacts) and treasure hunts that yields you a single Epic class gear.Is it fun : Extremely.Does have any flaws : Yes. As with all fun games you want more. I would have liked if it had more classes ( rogues , scouts..etc. ), out of combat focus even if it was just yes or no choices and steam work shop support for player created campaigns.Verdict : Very fun game to play with amazing content to match 8/10      Tl;dr : Xcom meets D&D in a weird card game like manner , easy to play hard to master, free to play , turn based , amazing content , paying unlocks more amazing content , wish it had more things to do other than combat.

												Card Hunter is all of the fun of Dungeons and Dragons with none of the hassle of dice, rules lawyers, bad role players, metagamers, that one guy even the geeks want to smack about, cards, pens, paper, character sheets. Posted: July 25, 2015
												I recommend this game but with reservations.  Lets start by saying I really enjoy(ed) this game.  Its a very cool idea.  I love the way they made it a turn-based, RPG, table-top looking game and integrated it with a card collecting game.  Very unique and a breath of fresh air.  The graphics are absolutely wonderful.  Game play is challenging but still very easy to pick up.   But...and there's always a but...I don't believe in playing games with in-app purchases.  The best I can tell, you get your characters to level 8 and there is no more new content without paying.  You can revisit old dungeons or create new characters and level them up to 8 but, if you don't want to pay then the game stops at level 8.  I know what free-to-play means, it just would have been nice to have a no-frills, no-pay option.  You know, complete the game for free or destroy everything in your path for money.  Anyway, I still recommend this game because it was a ton of fun getting them to 8 but truthfully I uninstalled it shortly after that.I should add I didn't try the multiplayer and hated the special impossible dungeons.  Maybe the multiplayer ones would bring more fun to the "table".  LOL, see what I did there?

Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is charming and very interesting. If you are a fan of tabletop games, such as Dungeong and Dragons, I would recommend getting this. They have a card member club feature that unlocks more content, and after playing for an hour I am thinking of joining the club, and it also allows for you to buy different increments of the club membership including a 7 day membership, which I think is pretty cool. You don't have to commit to a 30 day membership. The games graphics are not complex, but they are charming and work for the genre, and the dialogue is rather funny.The combat system is based off of card draws from a deck, and it is rather intracate. I can tell it was designed well, and I did not find any bugs. I did however find some frustration in the right cards being drawn from the deck each round, but I suppose that is all part of enjoying a deck card type game.I would at least try this out.
