Posted: July 26, 2015
												Card Hunter exemplifies my favorite kind of RPG--that which feels old-school and nostalgic while having modern and/or interesting mechanics. The banter between dorky DM and his nerdier older brother contrasts with the sword-and-sorcery adventures your party goes on, bringing back memories of Friday nights in high school, while the gameplay itself aims to emulate, but not copy those games and the offshoots like Baldur's Gate and Pillars of Eternity.One might argue that the free to play aspect makes this incomparable to those full-fledged CRPG's, but I personally prefer it. It is easy to jump in and out of the game, going on small adventures instead of dedicating several hours to progression. They really have nailed that aspect of playing D&D in person without cleaving to the social commitment a pnp game requires. I don't know if I personally will throw up the cash for pizza slices (the IAP premium currency), but I haven't gotten far enough in the game yet to need them.My only complaint with the mechanics so far is that there isn't a print-and-play version available to try Card Hunter in meatspace. I don't think it would work nearly as well as this version, but I do hope more pnp RPG's take note and try something similar in the future.

												I was a little unsure at first about a union of D&D and cards.Never have I been happier to be wrong.  This game is exactly what I didn't know I had been looking for.The game perfectly and seamlessly blends the tabletop feeling of dungeons and dragons, with the amazing combat system this game has created.  The AI is somewhat intelligent - I'm still pre level 10 - and while I wish it was a little more challenging in terms of the enemy health and skills. Posted: July 31, 2015
												As a person who has put a fair amount of time into the game I have to say that this game was something I really wanted to like. It had many components that you would think would fit perfectly well, but the main problem with this game is: The game has this repetitive grind to it because it makes you fight the RNG (random number generater),especially near the end of the campaign. The missions/modules/enemies always seem to have a major advantage. Never have I seen an enemy without at least one attack nomatter what when they draw while more than likely I seem to go for rounds without getting anything but move cards. Enemies sometimes come in hordes which seem not bad since most hordes just share form a single deck but the problem start to arise when you notice that while you take a whole turn to move one character, for the enemy actually takes one turn to move everyone.Theres also the fact that the enimes have better cards than you most of the time which don't make much sense for the levels sice you can only come in within certain levels and if your overlevelled then you have to lose some cards and power tokens to make it "fair"The game rolls seems rigged. I can't tell how many times that this game gave me a hand that could comlete annilate a foe but for some reason ALL its defence cards block everything, even when my cards have stuff like "hard to block" or they have "bad luck"(it essentially makes it s the dice roll goes down by 1), it gets so lucky and procs each and every block card.I mean theres one level in particular which is called "Return to the Astral Shrine" which essentially is impossible for me because even with armour destoying cards, bad luck and any other cards that make enemies lose cards, the enemies in that room just make it impossible because thay always have a card that blocks 5 damage, they only need to roll a 4 ad it doesn't matter whether is works or not they keep that card. But the problem with that is that they seem to always have one of those cards in there hand no matter how many times you destroy it! I mean I once save two cards that did 14 damage each so I unleashed it on one foe and it happend to have two armour cards which successfully rolled a +4 for both of the attacks I did, which lead to my attack that had the chance to do 28 damage to do a total of 8.Overall, I think that this game has it's charm but the fact that even though it's free to play, it feels like it tries to rig the game and force you to buy so that you can actually progress.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												Overall I love Card Hunter. They were able to successfully blend my favorite aspects of gaming into one epic package. Between the campaign mode and multiplayer, I could easily see myself logging hundreds of hours into this game if I had the free time to do so. The only reason I can’t give this a solid 5/5 is due to the micro-transactions along with the expansions and club membership. They are just being a little too greedy when it comes to sucking money out of the pockets of fellow gamers, and games like these are hard for me to recommend on a moral level. If someone who respects my opinions got hooked onto this game and ends up spending thousands of dollars due to micro-transactions, I couldn’t help but feel slightly responsible. If you are not someone that is easily suckered into this business scheme, then I highly recommend this game. You can enjoy Card Hunter without ever spending a dime, or at least never buying any Pizza. If you are someone that can’t help but spend money in a game in order to gain the upper hand or speed up the grinding process, I urge to you to stay away from this game, and any others that condone this set-up.Check out my full review on our site, and feel free to let me know what you thought of my opinions!  http://www.steamfirst.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=10267&action=edit

Posted: August 19, 2015
												Don't get me wrong it's a nice concept, a simplified version of DnD without the hastle of trying to learn how to build characters through an ocean of content. But the way it is now some things need to change. Most situations feel like they need to be handled by more then 3 team members and the game overwhelms you in later missions with large amounts of NPCs that are both small damage and large damage leaning more in the favor of large damage enemies. Usually ending with you trying to prioritize the high damage enemies but taking too much damage or losses to consider the exchanges worth while.Pros:Simple:Easy to learn, your abilities are based on the equipment you have, enemies aren't overcomplicated time bombs you don't want to go near, races are genericly balanced, and classes have designated equips.Great Fun with Friends:Co-op with friends is a blast, makes everything twice as fun.Comedic Writing:The game can be funny at times making it feel more worthwile to play through the campaignEquiment:Easy to understand, a little hard to obtain without grinding lower level missions, and equipment is balanced with major and minor power tokens so you aren't a complete god against the AI.Easy to Change:You don't have to stick to one party, you can buy new party members for a low cost of ingame currency and interchange party members at any time to fit your play style.Cons:Classes aren't what they seem to be:The classes can be built one of two ways, either all aggression or complete support roles. There are no effective in betweens because you're either losing out on damage or don't help the other members in your team.Wizards aren't at all DPS, most spells at a wizard's disposal are weak or are easily snuffed out by enemy armors/blocks. Also most beginning damage spells are close range that deal no damage, meaning you have to sit in damage range just to do damage and this follows you well into mid game depending on your load out. The wizards that can control spells that manipulate the battlefield have no damage what so ever. Priests are squishy supports that can't stay in combat very long for the same reason, they do almost no damage. With the all aggression priests they have almost no support and once again can't stay in combat because they can't take a hit.Warriors are either high damage DPS with no range or medium DPS with range. Warriors aren't tanks either considering most NPCs will just chip off 50% or more of your member's HP without even trying. Warriors either move into range and then have the target immediatly move out of range afterwards or do little to no damage with longer range attacks.Equipment:It will screw you again and again, most equipment is either okay but nothing substantial. Anything that's good either has terrible draw backs from using them or require so many power tokens you can't use anything else that's good until you're high level. Your equipment is determind by RNG so you might just get a bunch of stuff for warriors or priests, but get nothing for your mage. Essentially making that unit completly worthless unless you do a grindfest or buy new overpriced equipment. Main issues with equipment is you're forced to use low level equipment even though your other gear is leagues ahead of it and it's mainly useless in your missions. There isn't any scaling in gear level, you have your low level gear that doesn't require power tokens, mid range gear that requires minor power tokens, and high grade gear that requires either major power tokens or both major and minor power tokens. At max level team members, you only get 4 major power tokens and 4 minor tower tokens. Which you have to try and prioritize certain equipment slots over others, making you weak extremely weak in one department and strong in another. The Warrior class has 9 equipment slots, Mage 10 slots, and Priests with 10 slots. With most late game gear using 2 major power tokens you're already missing half your stock for only one equipment item. So now you're stuck trying to build for pure DPS or pure support for certain classes. There is no effective inbetween for both offensive and defensive builds, they both work against each other and flood your hand with either or, not a mixture of both.Gold/Shop:Making gold is stupidly hard uphill battle of RNG and selling extra equipment for almost nothing to buy new equipment. To be actually able to sell back items you don't use you need to get a renown of 7, probably about 8 or so campaign missions. Their main reason in doing this is to have players build a good amount of equipment before going and blindly selling off equipment they aren't using. Main issue with this is once you get to sell items they aren't worth much of anything unless it's rare or legendary equipment which still sells for a crappy amount of gold. Common equipment is usually worth around one to two gold, where rare and legendary sell for around 50 to 100 gold. Selling one legendary piece of equipment gets you enough gold to buy one mediocre item from the shop. Your main way of making gold is selling common extras of equipment and cheap treasure with your occasional semi-precious treasure.NPCs and RNG are jerks:NPCs won't move unless you do most of time making it hard to determine how to plan for a situation, most times the NPCs seem to be well aware of what you possess in your hand. NPCs seem to just get cards that undermine everything you try to do. They either have so much armor and block you can't do anything or their rolls against you and for themselves feel rigged in their favor most of the time. Most of their saving rolls are 4+ and they seem to get the rolls they need flawlessly at most points in time. My armors and blocks have a saving roll of 2 or better and I still end up failing them 90% of the time.Races:The different races don't work well together at all. Dwarves are all tank but no movement which makes them pair terribly with humans and elves because they just leave them behind in the dust. If you're going to play with a dwarf you might as well make the rest of your party dwarves and play defensivly. The only good time to have one dwarf is as a mage because they don't have to be front line. Humans are a balance of both health and movement making them your go tos for optional play styles and are able to switch between aggressive and passive play styles. Elves are all mobility with no health making them get in and out characters or complete avoidance characters. You're not staying in combat with elves, you're either dashing in to do a little damage then dashing out or attacking from afar. Elves don't pair well with other races because they just leave the other races behind and end up over extending themselves.Little to no hand manipulation:There are barely any card draws and some of them punish you for trying to get new cards that are better for the situation. There is little to no enemy hand manipulation unless you can specificly build for it and land the ability through the NPC's/Player's saving roles. So far the only enemy hand manipulation cards I have seen remove their oldest block or all of them or remove armor cards. Enemy NPC's will most likely do this to themselves before you even know what to use to manipulate their hand.My current stand point with this game is neutral, I love the concept but hate the way the game is going at the moment. I'm left here to hope they change some of these glaring issues before I loose all interest for a game that punishes players for trying to build for multiple utilities. If you want to play it for fun's sake with friends you'll probably enjoy this game for a few sessions. But if you want to seriously play all the way to the end power to you, because this game is brutal with it's RNG and rolls for saves. To be able to continue to play for me there needs to be a serious rebalance with how classes work, how card draw works, and how the rolls/RNG work.

												Do you like dungeons and dragons?Do you like magic the gathering?This game is the offspring of those two games fantastic love child.The game is simple enough for anyone to pick up but challenging enough to keep you entertained, they have found the sweet spot of what a F2P is suppose to look like. micro transactions dont really influence the game outside of allowing you to explore more content although the free to play campaign offers more then enough to keep you enthralled.The muave manticore maps will really test your skills and your patience, but overall they offer something to break away from the norm the game has to offer. Posted: September 5, 2015
												An amazing little turn-based tactical strategy game with an old school fantasy RPG flavor.  Position your adventurers on a grid map and do battle with monsters using the spells and fighting techniques represented by cards that your adventurers get from the equipment you choose to equip them with.  It has a decent competative MOBA multiplayer as well as a 2-3 player co-op campaign.  The purple prose of the modules provokes just the right amount of nostalgia to invoke OG Dungeons and Dragons.  The competative balance ebbs and flows with each expansion, but is generally pretty good.  The difficulty of the singleplayer/coop campaign varies WILDLY depending on the specific scenerio, any handycaps you may choose to apply, and how you spec your toons.Expansions/DLC are fun and flavorful if somewhat short and occationally punishingly hard.Overall a very nicely designed TSG with a good deal of depth and a strong competitive following.  Can be a little hard even for a vetern of the genre in places, the campaign does get stale after a while, and it can be frustrating to grind for a single high level item among the multitude of random drops, but these complaints pale in comparison to the game's many charms.

Posted: September 1, 2015
												Card Hunter is all of the fun of Dungeons and Dragons with none of the hassle of dice, rules lawyers, bad role players, metagamers, that one guy even the geeks want to smack about, cards, pens, paper, character sheets.  It very much reminds me of the years I spent as a table top RPG player with none of the drawbacks. It's easy to pick up and play. Free or pay it's an awesome game either way! Grab it. The worst you'll lose is a few hours of your life without a dime out of pocket. Best case scenario, it becomes your newest guilty pleasure addiction.  Either way as a steam gamer you win.

Posted: August 2, 2015
												Card Hunter is a very unique experience; i would very loosely call it a mix of D&D, TCG to an extent but omitting the trading part of TCG and Chess. The graphics are not next generation and on the loading screen it says "A game only limited by your imagination" which is very true; if your expecting some next generation graphics this aint the game. Card Hunter's main premise is build around loot. You can dungeon for loot, battle other players online for loot, enter a league with special play/win conditions you wont find anywhere else for even better loot if you do well and as well you can buy loot, using the in-game currency known as 'Pizza' delivered by a pizza company donning the name of the development company, 'Blue Manchu'. I myself have bought a little bit of loot and the pay to win aspect you'd expect to be present gets kind of drowned out by the skill actually required to play the game and assemble an effective deck; in the time it will take you to learn the game, you will have earned probably the same amount of loot as you would just buying some off the start and not playing much of the content it has to offer and so in this sense, the game is not pay to win. When you get loot from dungeons or online, there is a loot club you can also sub to, using pizza, to get an extra roll off the chest; You can easily afford the 7 day membership to this club with the free pizza your given in-game throughout the beginning of the campgain and then finish the campgaign and get all the member loot you would miss if you didn't have it, but again, your use of whatever you get from these free rolls will only be dictated by your skill at the game and time spent, so its not really pay to win.The battles themselves are, by many who play this game, considered to be 'mentally taxing' and it is true, in battle your margine for error is very low. Basically, most maps will have a 'VS' or victory square, to which you can move your character to, and your character will sit on these points and control them; at the end of the round, if you control more points, you get a 'VP' or victory point, stating that you control the points, you get a single point. If he kills one of your chracters however, your opponent will get 2 'VP' and so although the 'VS' or victory squares are important, character management is far more important and these two factors working together in the game serve to create a very intense experience with low margine for error if you want to win. There are 6 VP's to gain in total and 3 characters on each team, so if you wipe his team, even if your losing on the Victory Squares, you can still come back and win.The races you can choose have a profound effect on the board; Elves are movement based and usually get 2-3 movement cards rather than just the standard 1 movement card every turn, but have the lowest HP of all the races. Dwarves have higher hit points, but are the slowest race. Humans are dynamic and have commands they can use to make their team members move, or draw cards and are considered to be the average race with average health and average movement. Getting in depth with classes is not necessary; there is the warrior, cleric and mage. Very simple. How you play these classes in context to what race you choose to play the class as will basically define your experience in the game and is a big choice to make right off the bat, considering you'll have spent no time playing the game before initially making this choice to choose race/class. Considering this game is free, it is a steal of a deal and i highly recommend you atleast try the game out; yes there is content that is behind a pay wall, however if you enjoy the game and think its well thought out and created, maybe 'Blue Manchu' deserves to make a little cash off it, huh? =)

Posted: March 15, 2016
												Great game full of nerdy D&D fun. There are plenty of pay to players out there, but due to the ranking system you don't have to fight them if you don't want to pay to play. The whole game depends on giving your characters equipment that works together, making an effective strategy in the match, and perhaps most of all, pure luck. I have beaten players many ranks higher than me, and have been beaten by players many ranks lower than me. This game is designed well enough to separate the pay to players and the casual players. Anyone who gripes about pay to players probably just doesn't know how to strategize effectively or work with the cards they're given. The league matches with prebuilt decks are where a players true colors show. Many times I have beaten higher ranked players when given even playing fields.Overall its a really fun game if you don't take it too seriously. Also there is an editor where you can build your own maps and scenarios which is awesome.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												A fun, laid back, yet deceptively deep and addictive experience. Card hunter plays like a board game complete with cut out characters and your own decks to build. Your character can progress in level, but the main way to get better is to equip better gear. Every piece of equipment puts different cards into your deck. These cards are then payed during the turn-based sessions. Complete those and you'll get loot and money to improve your characters. Nice and easy, but still fun.Best of all is that this game is free. You can pay for additional campaigns or different skins for your characters, but everything is optional. As far as I can see, this is no pay to win. I can't speak for the mulitplayer portion however.

Posted: August 7, 2015
												This is a pretty addictive game and enjoyable, don’t expect the depth and richness of something like magic as it’s simpler than that but that’s part of the charm.IMHO I wouldn't say it's a pay-to-win the reason being the currency, being pizza and gold, can be earned through the single player campaign. The only advantages of paying include: > Getting more items – You get more items during the campaign, there are treasure hunt adventures that can get you more items, and you can get more gold to get more items.> Cosmetic – You can get additional avatars> League games – You can join multiplayer leagues games, and if you win you can actually get gold, pizza and items anyway.This basically means that you can get items faster, but you can always get items playing the FREE multiplayer 1v1 anyway, and that you can play the league games which are enjoyable. Overall it’s worth a go.

												now it's not often i put money into a free game.  the only Free 2 Play game i've put any money at all into was Warframe and that's only because i didn't want to get rid of my stuff (collection nut here :P ) but Card Hunters is just so fricken great that i'd put money into it.  it mixes tabletop DND with a deck building game where your character's equipment decides what cards are in your deck, then when you've equipped your characters, it tosses you into battles where you're literally looking down at a board with your characters as little, old-fashioned, flat cardboard pieces on plastic stands.  it's so damn cool!  as a 90s kid i grew up playing board games with pieces like that so this is a total throwback, but at the same time it's fresh, new, and just so god damn cool!  there's nothing else to say.  out of 5 stars, this gets 1,000,000!  some may say this is a bit over the top, but i just love this game!  plain and simple!  just love it to little bitsies! *squee* and i'm done.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												I'm a fan of deck-building games, but this isn't really recommendable.This is fun for the first 6-8 character levels.  There is a nice table-top RPG flavor with the nerdy Dungeon Master commenting on the little adventures.  It is a little taste of nostalgia for those who used to play D&D in the old days.I can't recommend this because outside of the nostalgia hit with light humor this isn't much game here.And while it was entertaining enough for a few hours of entertainment, if you do not have a perfect internet connection the game will drop you and force you to reconnect to the server.  Repeatedly.There is seriously no reason an extremely simple single-player campaign game like this needs to be connected to the server at all times.  It smacks of blizzard's implementation of the new Starcraft, except this game is free.It is hard to lose at lower levels, but as you get to around level 8 dungeons suddenly things get ridiculous.  A shark-bear ate my cleric in the first round with three bites, destroying her armor with the first bite.  A shark-bear is mildly humorous... but, meh.Then I went back to the board and my question asking, "Why is there a ridiculous constant internet connection requirement?" was removed from the board.I read the negative review stating that around level 10 you need to start buying the in-game pizza currency with real money to be competitive.Then I deleted Card Hunter from my game library.  It was kind of wacky and mildly fun for a bit, but that's it.

Posted: July 19, 2015
												I'd never been a fan of tabletop games, or even card games, prior to being introduced to Hearthstone. Now, it seems, I can't get enough of the latter. Card Hunter combines everything that there is to like in CCGs (although here you have loot that gives cards rather than actual card collecting) with everything there is to like in RPGs, and the end result is something really special. The game is constantly rewarding, and you're never left feeling like you HAVE to spend cash on Pizza (the premium currency) to keep up. The campaign is fun, with the distinctly tabletop chunks of text describing each mission. Missions can be either a sort of campaign, where there are some interconnecting bits of story, or dungeon-crawling treasure hunts with a guaranteed high-rarity reward. The multiplayer (I've only played a few games of it though) is far more rewarding than any other free-to-play game that I've encountered. You get a reward chest for every win 1-20 DAILY.Did I mention there's coop?

												I played this game a lot during closed and open beta.  This game has that fun yet frustrating feel to it.  Blocks and Armor cards that your enemies carry can ruin your best laid plans.  Don't take this game for a technical and customizable strategy game like Final Fantasy Tactics.  This game is probably 50/50 luck to planning. Imagine Final Fantasy Tactics if each character in your party has a Hearthstones deck. That's this game.  It's free to play, so the price can't be beat.  The premium mode purchased with in game cash, aka Pizza, gets you an extra item after every battle.  If you plan on playing more, that extra item is really useful.  Many times that item matches the best rarity of the item you got from your chest. Got 1 epic in your chest?  Now you might get 2.Pros: Short battles (most of the time)Customizable strategiesFlexible partiesLots of cards and itemsEasy to learnCons:Stupid, no reason lag, especially after playing a card.Only 3 party members per teamtimegated (sort of. Posted: July 20, 2015
												I'm going to start off by saying that I really love this game! Even though it may seem repetitive, I have not yet become even the slightest bit bored at any point, and I currently have a level 10 team, so not too bad so far considering I've had the game for two days! Campaign Mode - Okay, so with this mode, we're accompanied by Gary and Melvin, two 'CPU' versions of the card/board game competitors. Some of their lines are actually really funny, and they've not annoyed me yet which is surprising consdiering everything annoys me haha. Basically, what's great about campaign is that, at first, it's really easy to win and learn how to play, but once you start to get the hang of things, it becomes more difficult - to the point where it may take more than one attempt to beat the level - and this is obviously a technique to prevent boredom. The levels are of course possible, but they are challenging and require you to be strategic, which I love. There are many shops with many different types of weaponary and equipment, most of which are affordable. The characters have great customisation, including names which I think is a great detail, though it's small. It really feels like the team is yours and you know everything they can and can't do. Speaking of the characters, there are three per party. A warrior, mage and priest (healer). I'll explain the main pros and cons of each that I've noticed.Warrior: Pros - Good attacks and defenses, Cons - You have to be up close to use the attacks which makes your warrior vulnerable to attacksMage: Pros - Attacks from a distance, Cons - Low health, no armourPriest: Pros - Can heal the whole team repeatedlty, Cons - Not a lot of good attacks and defensesBut yeah, overall for campaign, everything is really great - characters, equipment, weaponary, levels, difficulty, even the dialogue is fun haha.Multiplayer Mode - I haven't played too much of this mode, but overall I like this too. You're always matched against someone on a similar multiplayer level as you, which makes the match fair, and everyone's team is levelled to the exact same also. Since in this mode your team is at the highest level, you can pretty much use whichever weapons you want to, whereas you can't do that in campaign as the level you are at limits what you use to fight with, which is understandable levelling. But the weapons you use in multiplayer mode are what you own in campaign mode, but both parties are different in each mode if you want them to be. So yeah, I definitely recommend getting this game if you like this kind of thing, and hey, it's free, what do you have to lose?

Posted: July 18, 2015
												This is a great game that does F2P right. The game is a blend of turn based Dungeons & Dragons style battles with a collectible card game. Blue Manchu has managed to combine the two types of game quite well. Each piece of equipment you attach to a character has a set of cards associated with it. This allows the player to quickly change their deck without going through and micromanaging every single card. In battle, the cards are drawn randomly from the pool each character has and are used to take actions. Movement, healing, attacking, and other status effects are all invoked by cards. This makes battles dynamic, interesting, and random.There is quite a bit of content for free but the game can get a bit grindy at higher levels. Several expansion modules have been released that can be purchased in game. There are also a few other perks that can be purchased, such as an increase in loot drops and additional character images. None of this is necessary to enjoy the game and there is plenty to do without paying a dime. Blue Manchu has balanced the difficult task of having a free game that is not pay to win and is worth paying a few dollars for for players who really enjoy it. I would recommend getting the additional modules, as they are pretty fun and help level up a bit quicker.I first played this game when it first came out so my Steam playtime doesn't represent my full playtime. I had taken a break from it and saw that it was added to Steam. With the Steam release is the new co-op feature. This allows a person to each control a character and take turns. This has been a lot of fun with friends and adds another element to the game since it requires focusing on a single character rather than the whole team.I would highly recommend this game for RPG and CCG fans. The two genres are blended perfectly to create a unique and engaging experience. There's nothing else really like it.

Posted: July 19, 2015
												I wanted to like this game, but once you get past the introductory campaign (and even somewhat during it), it effectively becomes pay-to-progress, as you get effectively zero money from drops, and you can't sell the majority of what you DO pick up until "later in the campaign", which does you no good when your inventory is full of crap drops (and a few that you can't use untill you either level or get a new character).  Battle system is...passable, but that's part of the problem - you need boots that get you more, longer movement in order to catch an enemy type that likes to retreat, but those cost upwards of 150, and since you can't sell things you no longer need you have no money except for the rare "treasure" drops (which aren't labelled as rare half the time, BTW), you're stuck either with a full inventory or shelling out real-world cash for in-game cash in order to buy the thing that lets you catch the enemy.  Or both.

Posted: February 22, 2016
												I admit I expected nothing from a free game but a couple of unrewarding hours of obsessive compulsive looting and lots of micro-transaction requests. Instead, I found an amazingly fun, well balanced and TOTALLY NOT Pay-per-Win gem that I can't get bored of.In these times of crappy cellphone-like games copying each other shamelessly, it's so refreshing to find such an original twist to the classic collectible cards and board games. It has a soft learning curve but, as new cards and enemies appear, the strategies to play multiply fast.The campaign and challenges are extremely fun to play, and the multiplayer is designed so you will not be abused by richer users, even if you never paid a cent. It's just one of those games that will have you playing "just one more level" all night long.Damn, I love this game!

Posted: March 6, 2016
												This game was exactly what I was looking for. I love card based games in the real world, but don't always have others to play against. This one will sometimes really make you think, as sometimes the cards you get won't be ideal - just like any real stategist game. Work with what you have. Cards available to each character will vary depending on what is in the deck for that character, and that is based on what items are equipped to the character. Because of this, no scenerio will ever play out exactly the same, even if you've already played that level before. Levels also follow storylines, so if you like to feel like you're fighting for a specific cause, you'll have one. Stop those gnolls from eating the villagers!

Posted: March 9, 2016
												Once you get past the mandatory tutorial (which may seem a bit long, but will help you grip the mechanics of the game) this game is a treasure gem in recent RPGs.The graphics are really nice with their comic touch and also allow low-end computers to enjoy the game.The vast inventory of items that you can acquire is pure awesome.It is fun and addictive, and still very challenging. I found playing co-op with some friends really made the game even more awesome.While I would like more costumes (customization <3), those that are is quite cool. Downsides include the quite annoying "game master" that jumps around every now and then. He is fun in the tutorial, but we should be able to turn him off later on. The notion that you can pay to earn better gear is not good, but still doesn't break the game IMO. This is not a pay-to-win game, but it does give you an advantage in the beginning.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												Very cool game about a game.  D-n-Desque single and co-op that has a nice interface and unique (at least to me)  game play.  Basically you are playing against the DM on various maps and the goal is to complete 3 missions per scenario.  Each mission is progressively tougher.  It is your team against the DM.  In turn based combat you cast spells, attack, or move about the board to defeat the oponent or achieve specific goals.  You do this by drawing random cards from your deck.  Your deck is built, based upon the type of equipment you are wearing or using.  So a certain shield might give you three cards, two of which are defence and one offence.  A certain sword would give you 5 attacks.  As you get higher in level you are able to use better equipement and get better cards.  This is an excellent, simple, well put together game.  And it's free!  Of course you can make micro-purchases which I have done.  It helps get better equipment and scenarios (free game has a ton, though).  Mostly I made the purchase to support the developers.  An excellent and fun game that is worthy of earning some real coin.  I see some comments regarding a need to pay to progress.  Not true.  I have played solo and with freinds (max 3 per group so far).  We just now, at lvl 9+, decided to purchase items and only as support of devs.  Maybe this need is true at higher levels but even so, considering the time we have into it, I'd say the cost is very reasonable.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												A Dungeons and Dragons-type, isometric, overhead, retro, tactics game, Card Hunter has consumed about 3 months of my life. Players compete against AI and other humans over Steam or over the Browser and play cards to move, deal damage, heal hitpoints, or change the rules of the tiles players stand on, in a 3v3 or 3 vs bot arenas.  A simple overarching storyline tells the tale of Mary Mymax's game (a nod to the great Gary Gymax from Dungeons and Dragon's fame.)  A second expansion came out last summer.  There are halloween items and a christmas store, and new battles are fireing every 30 seconds successfully against players.  Come join the thousands of people to play this game. Personally, 4 out of my 6 rarest achievments out of 1600+ achievements are from Card Hunter, so you're taking the advice of an addict.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												I am far from finishing this game, but what I have played is very charming.  I like the fusion of old school paper and pencil (and miniature) role-playing, and collectible card game mechanics.  The cards in your deck, and the actions you can take, are all determined by the gear your character equips.  Everything in the game is touched with a humor that lightly mocks gamer culture nerdiness, while obviously also being a love letter to the same.  I like the art style, which kinda skirts the line between Munchkin art and classic old-school game art.  The most important thing is that it actually plays well, and is a lot of fun.Oh, also, its free to play.  So try it.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												This is the best free turn based strategy game I've ever played.It has solo, 2-3 player coop and versus. So you can enjoy it however you want.The best part about the game is the item system. Each character have a deck of cards like attacks, armor, move, block... This deck is made by the items your character has equiped. Each item gives between 3 and 6 cards. But, it's all or nothing. If an item have 5 great cards and an handicap, you have to deal with it. This makes for very unique character building that can be optimized in a lot of ways.There is also 3 classes and 3 races for characters that all have items that can exclusively be equiped to them.There is a freaking lot of items in this game and, yep, it's free to play, you can buy more items. But it's not really a problem to me. You will lack some items in the begining but if you play through a good part of the campaign, you'll have a lot of them. If you want to help the devs your options are : timed subscription for an extra item after each fight, buying individual chests with guaranteed high rarity items and new side-missions with guarantee item the first time you complete it. None of those are required to truly enjoy the game. There is also some character reskin you can buy that doesn't affect gameplay at all.(If you want to buy the missions, the bundle isn't you only option. If you go on the lock mission, you'll be able to unlock it for some paid currency which is a better deal if you don't care about the rest of the bundle.)The campaing itself it very fun. Each mission is a different challenge with unique opponents. I've yet to complete it. The missions get harder and harder, often requiring you to change your items to match specific opponents. I've started it again with a friend and it still is a blast to play.But, the story is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Don't expect anything from that part.An amazing strategy game that gives you a lor of options and always harder challenges. Solo, coop and versus, all are amazing!

Posted: July 27, 2015
												So far (62 hours played) this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played.Likes:- Well-built, runs smoothly and no crashes.- Looks good, original artwork that suits its slightly wacky style.- Entertaining gameplay in matches.  Most are challenging enough to be fun without being frustrating.  Some are very challenging, making you think carefully about team build and every card you play.- Interesting party building.  Three classes, three races and a huge number of loot cards gives enough variety to make your parties feel unique.- Good value for money.  I bought one expansion, which gives me a months club membership and few other bits, but I am quite certain you can play the campaign without struggling for free.  Multiplayer does have the capacity for being influenced by spending money, but at my level I've not seen any of that.- Fun PvP.  Played about 10 matches so far.  All players I have met have been friendly and only one or two matches have been one-sided.  The others have been nicely balanced and very entertaining.- Awesome humour.  If you every played much PnP Dungeons and Dragons, this game will make you smile and chuckle constantly.- Good community.  The world chat is mostly good-natured.  For a competitive game there is a surprising lack of leetness and rage.Dislikes:- Literally not found any yet.  I suspect that if I get to high-rating PvP, balance issues might start to appear, but none so far.

												Card Hunter is a fun and smart game offering an intriguing mix of strategic combat and loot collection. It's a worthwhile adventure, often difficult, with significant replay for those who want to collect the vast variety of loot available. 												The game is fine, but progression is slow, feels repetitive, and it lacks the type of customization and character building that a game like this should have.  Why must we be unable to choose the gender of our characters, and be forced to use warrior, mage, and priest.  Also, the card style is rather odd; but I understand why they would go with it.But you know; it's a free game, and it's pretty fun for a while.  So you might as well give it a try and see if you enjoy it.  Just don't go into here thinking from all the other reviews that this is anything close to a real D&D experience; because it most definitely is not; and that type of thinking will just make you disappointed.Also; it feels like poor practice that they rub it in your face every time you complete a mission that you do not have the paid subscription.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												Card Hunter.Judging from the reviews this is a game most people either love or hate. So, what is it like?Well, first off it's turn based strategy with a game board theme, so don't expect tremendous graphics, or RTS action. It's played on a board, with cardboard-style characters. If you've played classic table-top D&D you'll have the general idea.The player has a team of 3 characters. I chose all dwarves, which seemed to work fine, as they have plenty of health and their lack of movement can be compensated by giving them extra movement cards. Warrior, mage, cleric, all good in their own ways. The player start with 5 movement/attack cards and draws 3 more each turn. The draws are random, so expect to lose a few boards because you get terrible draws. Generally, though, the boards are testing and interesting, but not strategically hard, as long as you equip your people with sensible weapons, armours, and abilities. It's not the same game as, say, Wesnoth, obviously, but is at around the same tactical difficulty level. Blocks and armours do matter, and as you play more, you'll begin to see how the mechanics work, what cards you need to keep, etc.I tried multiplayer - it was good fun, and you get much better equipment, to ensure a level playing field.Card hunter is 'free to play'; I haven't felt the need to buy anything so far -  up to level 14. That of course may change, as the challenges get harder.Try it for free - if you don't like it, play something else; after all, it doesn't cost anything to try!

Posted: July 25, 2015
												I recommend this game but with reservations.  Lets start by saying I really enjoy(ed) this game.  Its a very cool idea.  I love the way they made it a turn-based, RPG, table-top looking game and integrated it with a card collecting game.  Very unique and a breath of fresh air.  The graphics are absolutely wonderful.  Game play is challenging but still very easy to pick up.   But...and there's always a but...I don't believe in playing games with in-app purchases.  The best I can tell, you get your characters to level 8 and there is no more new content without paying.  You can revisit old dungeons or create new characters and level them up to 8 but, if you don't want to pay then the game stops at level 8.  I know what free-to-play means, it just would have been nice to have a no-frills, no-pay option.  You know, complete the game for free or destroy everything in your path for money.  Anyway, I still recommend this game because it was a ton of fun getting them to 8 but truthfully I uninstalled it shortly after that.I should add I didn't try the multiplayer and hated the special impossible dungeons.  Maybe the multiplayer ones would bring more fun to the "table".  LOL, see what I did there?

Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is charming and very interesting. If you are a fan of tabletop games, such as Dungeong and Dragons, I would recommend getting this. They have a card member club feature that unlocks more content, and after playing for an hour I am thinking of joining the club, and it also allows for you to buy different increments of the club membership including a 7 day membership, which I think is pretty cool. You don't have to commit to a 30 day membership. The games graphics are not complex, but they are charming and work for the genre, and the dialogue is rather funny.The combat system is based off of card draws from a deck, and it is rather intracate. I can tell it was designed well, and I did not find any bugs. I did however find some frustration in the right cards being drawn from the deck each round, but I suppose that is all part of enjoying a deck card type game.I would at least try this out.

												A fun, laid back, yet deceptively deep and addictive experience. Card hunter plays like a board game complete with cut out characters and your own decks to build. Your character can progress in level, but the main way to get better is to equip better gear. Every piece of equipment puts different cards into your deck. These cards are then payed during the turn-based sessions. Complete those and you'll get loot and money to improve your characters. Nice and easy, but still fun.Best of all is that this game is free. You can pay for additional campaigns or different skins for your characters, but everything is optional. As far as I can see, this is no pay to win. I can't speak for the mulitplayer portion however.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												Card Hunter is one of the best co-op turn-based strategy games in existence. Enough said there.Given there's no true pay to win or catchup mechanisms, however, PvP tends to be won by the guy who's been around the longest. Since this PvP is what most would consider the endgame, this means that the game eats itself as it ages. Attempts have been made at making the game more evangelical. Leagues, particularly limited format ones, are incredible, and maps you create can be added to the game in the Mauve Manticore dungeons, which are finally firing once per month like they stated when they first devised the idea. Further, Aloyzo's Arsenal allows players to submit custom items which can be added to the game.The issue here is that none of their evangelical work gets to the heart of the problem, which is that their loot design denies new players the ability to try entire categories of strategies - burst mage and vampire priest being the worst offenders - for their first months of playtime. And if a set of ranked maps favors these old-player builds for that month, well, Card Hunter likely has lower new player retention that month.Basically, the game needs to ensure that there's no exclusivity. Stay to win is almost as bad as pay to win.Still, play the PvE. It's incredible, and you'll have a blast.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												This game was exactly what I was looking for. I love card based games in the real world, but don't always have others to play against. This one will sometimes really make you think, as sometimes the cards you get won't be ideal - just like any real stategist game. Work with what you have. Cards available to each character will vary depending on what is in the deck for that character, and that is based on what items are equipped to the character. Because of this, no scenerio will ever play out exactly the same, even if you've already played that level before. Levels also follow storylines, so if you like to feel like you're fighting for a specific cause, you'll have one. Stop those gnolls from eating the villagers!

Posted: March 5, 2016
												The game starts off well enough, and is Thoroughly enjoyable. But by the time you hit level 6 you'll start noticing power discrepancies. By level 8, it has become a major annoyance, When you start getting close to level 10, you will find yourself consistently out numbered, starting in bad positions, against enemies that can deal far more damage than you can consistently and with defences that negate entire swaths of cards, and healing abilities far above your own. Eventually, it becomes unplayable.Worse, this is not the fault of bad gear and cannot simply be bought out of as with so called pay-to-win games. Good gear is abundant, you just can’t use any of it due to the horrible pedantic power node system.Looking at the game’s pedigree, including staff from Irrational Games/Looking Glass studios and advisers from Magic the Gathering, one of two things comes to mind. You would either expect the game to be phenomenal, or you still have painful memories of Bioshock: Infinite and Modern Format. Sadly, I have to say that it starts as the first and quickly moves towards the later.

Posted: March 15, 2016
												Great game full of nerdy D&D fun. There are plenty of pay to players out there, but due to the ranking system you don't have to fight them if you don't want to pay to play. The whole game depends on giving your characters equipment that works together, making an effective strategy in the match, and perhaps most of all, pure luck. I have beaten players many ranks higher than me, and have been beaten by players many ranks lower than me. This game is designed well enough to separate the pay to players and the casual players. Anyone who gripes about pay to players probably just doesn't know how to strategize effectively or work with the cards they're given. The league matches with prebuilt decks are where a players true colors show. Many times I have beaten higher ranked players when given even playing fields.Overall its a really fun game if you don't take it too seriously. Also there is an editor where you can build your own maps and scenarios which is awesome.

												It's a good mix between a Magic card game and old-school turn-based D&D games. This is the best free game I've ever gotten from Steam. There are so many bad games in this niche. This is a good one. content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												My buddy and I got this game because it seemed like an interesting little time-waster that we could get a psuedo pen-and-paper feel from. It ended up being more strategically interesting and pretty damn good fun to play with a little bit of the rebel yell in your system (that's whiskey). We haven't given multiplayer arena a shot, but for a free game we didn't have too many complaints. If you play co-op campaign though, and you don't have a third person (and you or your buddy are now drunk on said whiskey) it can get a bit more challenging. You do get more cards with two people, but you can't diversify as well. There are some adventures that benefit more from three medicore charcters than two very good ones. A lot of reviews claim this game is too hard, especially with terrain effects. I think those folks are getting frustrated because they can't play the game in a SPECIFIC way. We banged our heads against those maps a little bit, but generally found that we could do just as well with a little creative thinking, and more whiskey.

Posted: July 15, 2015
												This is a really fun, really unique game. I am personally a fan of tabletop games, and enjoyed this. The combat is rather well done, and the game very much feels like an actual tabletop- if a little simplistic. HOWEVER. THere are issues. I cannot tell you how many times the game has become stuck in the short time I've played it. It will feeze during attacks, during movement, hell, half the time it gets stuck on an infinate loading screen going to the MAIN MENU when you START UP THE GAME. And for the record, while my PC is in no way a top-of-the-line gaming machine, it can run most other games I feel the need to play on the highest graphics settings. This may be a problem that I alone have experienced, but it had sadly made the game needlessly difficult to play. Thankfully, there is an autosave feature every turn, so if you have to exit out of the game when it gets stuck, it will put you right back where you left off. I still reccomend this game, but I also feel obligated to warn you about these very troubling issues that I, personally, have experienced.

												This game took me by surprise. It's more or less a D&D knockoff and as a kid I played an actual board game that was similar to D&D. To anyone that is skeptical of the game, just give it a decent go and try to reach level 7 and try to play with friends before deciding that you don't want to play this game. Card Hunter is a game with simple graphics and a simple idea that ends up being really fun in the end, you can sit back with your friends and play through the campaign together in co-op mode or you can go through it solo, or you can join the mulitplayer arena and do some PVP.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												Don't get me wrong it's a nice concept, a simplified version of DnD without the hastle of trying to learn how to build characters through an ocean of content. But the way it is now some things need to change. Most situations feel like they need to be handled by more then 3 team members and the game overwhelms you in later missions with large amounts of NPCs that are both small damage and large damage leaning more in the favor of large damage enemies. Usually ending with you trying to prioritize the high damage enemies but taking too much damage or losses to consider the exchanges worth while.Pros:Simple:Easy to learn, your abilities are based on the equipment you have, enemies aren't overcomplicated time bombs you don't want to go near, races are genericly balanced, and classes have designated equips.Great Fun with Friends:Co-op with friends is a blast, makes everything twice as fun.Comedic Writing:The game can be funny at times making it feel more worthwile to play through the campaignEquiment:Easy to understand, a little hard to obtain without grinding lower level missions, and equipment is balanced with major and minor power tokens so you aren't a complete god against the AI.Easy to Change:You don't have to stick to one party, you can buy new party members for a low cost of ingame currency and interchange party members at any time to fit your play style.Cons:Classes aren't what they seem to be:The classes can be built one of two ways, either all aggression or complete support roles. There are no effective in betweens because you're either losing out on damage or don't help the other members in your team.Wizards aren't at all DPS, most spells at a wizard's disposal are weak or are easily snuffed out by enemy armors/blocks. Also most beginning damage spells are close range that deal no damage, meaning you have to sit in damage range just to do damage and this follows you well into mid game depending on your load out. The wizards that can control spells that manipulate the battlefield have no damage what so ever. Priests are squishy supports that can't stay in combat very long for the same reason, they do almost no damage. With the all aggression priests they have almost no support and once again can't stay in combat because they can't take a hit.Warriors are either high damage DPS with no range or medium DPS with range. Warriors aren't tanks either considering most NPCs will just chip off 50% or more of your member's HP without even trying. Warriors either move into range and then have the target immediatly move out of range afterwards or do little to no damage with longer range attacks.Equipment:It will screw you again and again, most equipment is either okay but nothing substantial. Anything that's good either has terrible draw backs from using them or require so many power tokens you can't use anything else that's good until you're high level. Your equipment is determind by RNG so you might just get a bunch of stuff for warriors or priests, but get nothing for your mage. Essentially making that unit completly worthless unless you do a grindfest or buy new overpriced equipment. Main issues with equipment is you're forced to use low level equipment even though your other gear is leagues ahead of it and it's mainly useless in your missions. There isn't any scaling in gear level, you have your low level gear that doesn't require power tokens, mid range gear that requires minor power tokens, and high grade gear that requires either major power tokens or both major and minor power tokens. At max level team members, you only get 4 major power tokens and 4 minor tower tokens. Which you have to try and prioritize certain equipment slots over others, making you weak extremely weak in one department and strong in another. The Warrior class has 9 equipment slots, Mage 10 slots, and Priests with 10 slots. With most late game gear using 2 major power tokens you're already missing half your stock for only one equipment item. So now you're stuck trying to build for pure DPS or pure support for certain classes. There is no effective inbetween for both offensive and defensive builds, they both work against each other and flood your hand with either or, not a mixture of both.Gold/Shop:Making gold is stupidly hard uphill battle of RNG and selling extra equipment for almost nothing to buy new equipment. To be actually able to sell back items you don't use you need to get a renown of 7, probably about 8 or so campaign missions. Their main reason in doing this is to have players build a good amount of equipment before going and blindly selling off equipment they aren't using. Main issue with this is once you get to sell items they aren't worth much of anything unless it's rare or legendary equipment which still sells for a crappy amount of gold. Common equipment is usually worth around one to two gold, where rare and legendary sell for around 50 to 100 gold. Selling one legendary piece of equipment gets you enough gold to buy one mediocre item from the shop. Your main way of making gold is selling common extras of equipment and cheap treasure with your occasional semi-precious treasure.NPCs and RNG are jerks:NPCs won't move unless you do most of time making it hard to determine how to plan for a situation, most times the NPCs seem to be well aware of what you possess in your hand. NPCs seem to just get cards that undermine everything you try to do. They either have so much armor and block you can't do anything or their rolls against you and for themselves feel rigged in their favor most of the time. Most of their saving rolls are 4+ and they seem to get the rolls they need flawlessly at most points in time. My armors and blocks have a saving roll of 2 or better and I still end up failing them 90% of the time.Races:The different races don't work well together at all. Dwarves are all tank but no movement which makes them pair terribly with humans and elves because they just leave them behind in the dust. If you're going to play with a dwarf you might as well make the rest of your party dwarves and play defensivly. The only good time to have one dwarf is as a mage because they don't have to be front line. Humans are a balance of both health and movement making them your go tos for optional play styles and are able to switch between aggressive and passive play styles. Elves are all mobility with no health making them get in and out characters or complete avoidance characters. You're not staying in combat with elves, you're either dashing in to do a little damage then dashing out or attacking from afar. Elves don't pair well with other races because they just leave the other races behind and end up over extending themselves.Little to no hand manipulation:There are barely any card draws and some of them punish you for trying to get new cards that are better for the situation. There is little to no enemy hand manipulation unless you can specificly build for it and land the ability through the NPC's/Player's saving roles. So far the only enemy hand manipulation cards I have seen remove their oldest block or all of them or remove armor cards. Enemy NPC's will most likely do this to themselves before you even know what to use to manipulate their hand.My current stand point with this game is neutral, I love the concept but hate the way the game is going at the moment. I'm left here to hope they change some of these glaring issues before I loose all interest for a game that punishes players for trying to build for multiple utilities. If you want to play it for fun's sake with friends you'll probably enjoy this game for a few sessions. But if you want to seriously play all the way to the end power to you, because this game is brutal with it's RNG and rolls for saves. To be able to continue to play for me there needs to be a serious rebalance with how classes work, how card draw works, and how the rolls/RNG work.
